Lie Algebra and Lie Groups

Smooth Differential Operators

A smooth differential operator of order nnn on MMM is a linear map P:C∞(M)→C∞(M)P: C^{\infty}(M) \to C^{\infty}(M)P:C∞(M)→C∞(M) that can be expressed locally as a finite sum of the form on each coordinate chart (U,x)(U,x)(U,x):

P=∑∣j∣≤naj(p)(∂∂x1)j1(∂∂x2)j2⋯(∂∂xm)jmP=\sum_{|j|\leq n} a_j(p) \left(\frac{\partial}{\partial x^1}\right)^{j_1}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial x^2}\right)^{j_2} \cdots \left(\frac{\partial}{\partial x^m}\right)^{j_m} P=∣j∣≤n∑​aj​(p)(∂x1∂​)j1​(∂x2∂​)j2​⋯(∂xm∂​)jm​

where aj(p)a_j(p)aj​(p) are smooth functions on MMM, m=dim⁡Mm=\dim Mm=dimM, and j=(j1,j2,…,jm)j=(j_1,j_2,\ldots,j_m)j=(j1​,j2​,…,jm​) is a multi-index with ∣j∣=j1+j2+…+jm|j|=j_1+j_2+\ldots+j_m∣j∣=j1​+j2​+…+jm​.

And by definition, a smooth vector field XXX on MMM is a smooth differential operator of order 111.

Using partition of unity, we can prove that any smooth differential operator can be expressed as composition of at most nnn smooth vector fields.

And supp⁡(Pf)⊆supp⁡(f)\operatorname{supp}(Pf) \subseteq \operatorname{supp}(f)supp(Pf)⊆supp(f) for any smooth function f∈C∞(M)f\in C^{\infty}(M)f∈C∞(M).

Peetre proves that any linear differential operator that satisfies the above condition is a smooth differential operator.

Lie Bracket on Smooth Vector Fields

Given two smooth vector fields X,YX,YX,Y on a smooth manifold MMM, the Lie bracket of XXX and YYY, denoted as [X,Y][X,Y][X,Y], on a local coordinate (U,ϕ)(U,\phi)(U,ϕ) it is defined as:

[X,Y]=X∘Y−Y∘X=∑i=1m(Xi∂Yj∂ϕi−Yi∂Xj∂ϕi)∂∂ϕj[X,Y]= X \circ Y - Y \circ X = \sum_{i=1}^m \left( X^i \frac{\partial Y^j}{\partial \phi^i} - Y^i \frac{\partial X^j}{\partial \phi^i} \right) \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi^j} [X,Y]=X∘Y−Y∘X=i=1∑m​(Xi∂ϕi∂Yj​−Yi∂ϕi∂Xj​)∂ϕj∂​

note the second order derivative is diminished, it is a the smooth vector field on MMM.

Generally speaking, if XXX is a differential operator of order ppp, YYY is of order qqq. X∘Y−Y∘XX\circ Y-Y\circ XX∘Y−Y∘X shall be a differential operator of order p+q−1p+q-1p+q−1.

The Lie bracket [⋅,⋅]:X(M)×X(M)→X(M)[\cdot,\cdot]: \mathfrak{X}(M) \times \mathfrak{X}(M) \to \mathfrak{X}(M)[⋅,⋅]:X(M)×X(M)→X(M) satisfy the following property for any X,Y,Z∈X(M)X,Y,Z\in\mathfrak{X}(M)X,Y,Z∈X(M)

  1. Antisymmetry: [X,Y]=−[Y,X][X,Y]=-[Y,X][X,Y]=−[Y,X]
  2. Jacobi Identity: [X,[Y,Z]]+[Y,[Z,X]]+[Z,[X,Y]]=0[X,[Y,Z]] + [Y,[Z,X]] + [Z,[X,Y]] = 0[X,[Y,Z]]+[Y,[Z,X]]+[Z,[X,Y]]=0.
  3. R\mathbb RR-Linearity: [aX+bY,Z]=a[X,Z]+b[Y,Z],∀a,b∈R[aX+bY,Z]=a[X,Z]+b[Y,Z],\forall a,b\in \mathbb R[aX+bY,Z]=a[X,Z]+b[Y,Z],∀a,b∈R

Note that it is not linear with respect to the second argument.

The Lie bracket gives a Lie Algebra structure on X(M)(Γ∞(TM))\mathfrak{X}(M)(\Gamma^{\infty}(TM))X(M)(Γ∞(TM)).

Integral Curves

Let X∈X(M)X\in \mathfrak{X}(M)X∈X(M), if a smooth curve γ:I→M\gamma: I \to Mγ:I→M is such that

γ˙(t)=Xγ(t)\dot \gamma(t) = X_{\gamma(t)} γ˙​(t)=Xγ(t)​

for all t∈It \in It∈I, then γ\gammaγ is called an integral curve of the vector field XXX.

if 0∈I0\in I0∈I, then γ(0)\gamma(0)γ(0) is called the initial point of the integral curve.

Example:

For the vector field X~=∑i=1nai∂∂xi\widetilde{X} = \sum_{i=1}^n a^i \frac{\partial}{\partial x^i}X=∑i=1n​ai∂xi∂​, the integral curve is:

γ~(t)=(c1+a1t,c2+a2t,…,cn+ant)\widetilde{\gamma}(t)=(c_1 + a^1 t, c_2 + a^2 t, \ldots, c_n + a^n t) γ​(t)=(c1​+a1t,c2​+a2t,…,cn​+ant)

where ci=γ(0)ic_i = \gamma(0)^ici​=γ(0)i are the initial point of the integral curve.

Assume γ\gammaγ is in a coordinate chart (U,x)(U,x)(U,x), we write ϕ(γ(t))=(x1(γ(t)),⋯ ,xn(γ(t)))\phi(\gamma(t))=(x^1(\gamma(t)),\cdots,x^n(\gamma(t)))ϕ(γ(t))=(x1(γ(t)),⋯,xn(γ(t))).

We denote γi:I→R=xi∘γ\gamma^i:I\to \mathbb{R}=x^i\circ \gammaγi:I→R=xi∘γ as the iii-th coordinate of γ\gammaγ on UUU.

γ˙(t)=(dγ)t(ddt)∣t=∑i=1n(dγ)t(ddt)∣t(xi)∂∂xi∣γ(t)=∑i=1nd(xi∘γ)dt∂∂xi∣γ(t)=∑i=1nγ˙i∂∂xi∣γ(t)\dot \gamma(t)=(d\gamma)_t(\frac{d}{dt})|_{t}=\sum_{i=1}^n (d\gamma)_t(\frac{d}{dt})|_{t}(x^i)\left.\frac{\partial}{\partial x^i}\right|_{\gamma(t)}=\sum_{i=1}^n\frac{d (x^i\circ \gamma)}{dt}\left.\frac{\partial}{\partial x^i}\right|_{\gamma(t)}=\sum_{i=1}^n \dot{\gamma}^i \left.\frac{\partial}{\partial x^i}\right|_{\gamma(t)} γ˙​(t)=(dγ)t​(dtd​)∣t​=i=1∑n​(dγ)t​(dtd​)∣t​(xi)∂xi∂​​γ(t)​=i=1∑n​dtd(xi∘γ)​∂xi∂​​γ(t)​=i=1∑n​γ˙​i∂xi∂​​γ(t)​

So the equation γ˙(t)=Xγ(t)\dot \gamma(t) = X_{\gamma(t)}γ˙​(t)=Xγ(t)​ can be written as:

∑i=1nγ˙i(t)∂∂xi∣γ(t)=∑i=1nXi(γ(t))∂∂xi∣γ(t)\sum_{i=1}^n \dot{\gamma}^i(t) \left.\frac{\partial}{\partial x^i}\right|_{\gamma(t)} = \sum_{i=1}^n X^i(\gamma(t)) \left.\frac{\partial}{\partial x^i}\right|_{\gamma(t)} i=1∑n​γ˙​i(t)∂xi∂​​γ(t)​=i=1∑n​Xi(γ(t))∂xi∂​​γ(t)​

So we have the system of ordinary differential equations:

γ˙i(t)=Xi∘x−1(γ1(t),…,γn(t))\dot{\gamma}^i(t) = X^i\circ x^{-1}(\gamma^1(t),\ldots,\gamma^n(t)) γ˙​i(t)=Xi∘x−1(γ1(t),…,γn(t))

for i=1,2,…,ni=1,2,\ldots,ni=1,2,…,n.

Conversely, every system of ordinary differential equations of the form above defines a unique integral curve γ\gammaγ on UUU of the vector field XXX.

By the existence and uniqueness theorem of ordinary differential equations on Rn\mathbb R^nRn, we have the following theorem:

Assume X∈X(M)X\in \mathfrak{X}(M)X∈X(M) is a smooth vector field on a smooth manifold MMM, then for every p∈Mp\in Mp∈M, there exists a neighborhood UUU of ppp, ϵ>0\epsilon>0ϵ>0 and a smooth mapping Γ:(−ϵ,ϵ)×U→M\Gamma: (-\epsilon,\epsilon) \times U \to MΓ:(−ϵ,ϵ)×U→M such that:

  1. Γ(0,p)=p\Gamma(0,p)=pΓ(0,p)=p for all p∈Up\in Up∈U.
  2. For fixed q∈Uq\in Uq∈U, γq(t)=Γ(t,q)\gamma_q(t)=\Gamma(t,q)γq​(t)=Γ(t,q) is the integral curve of XXX with initial point γq(0)=q\gamma_q(0)=qγq​(0)=q for all t∈(−ϵ,ϵ)t\in (-\epsilon,\epsilon)t∈(−ϵ,ϵ).
  3. The integral curve in [2][2][2] is unique in the sense that if σ:I→U\sigma: I \to Uσ:I→U is another smooth curve with σ(0)=q\sigma(0)=qσ(0)=q, then γq(t)=σ(t)\gamma_q(t)=\sigma(t)γq​(t)=σ(t) for all t∈(−ϵ,ϵ)∩It\in (-\epsilon,\epsilon)\cap It∈(−ϵ,ϵ)∩I.

Reparametrization

Generally, the reparametrization of an integral curve γ\gammaγ is not an integral curve of the vector field XXX. But if the reparametrization is linear, the reparametrization is still an integral curve of the vector field XXX.

If γ:I→M\gamma:I\to Mγ:I→M is an integral curve of XXX, then:

  1. Let Ia=t∣t+a∈II_{a}={t|t+a\in I}Ia​=t∣t+a∈I, γa:Ia→M\gamma_a:I_a\to Mγa​:Ia​→M be the curve defined by γa(t)=γ(t+a)\gamma_a(t)=\gamma(t+a)γa​(t)=γ(t+a) for all t∈Iat\in I_at∈Ia​. Then γa\gamma_aγa​ is also an integral curve of XXX.
  2. Let Ia=t∣at∈I(a≠0)I^{a}={t|at\in I} (a\neq 0)Ia=t∣at∈I(a=0), then γa:Ia→M,γa(t)=γ(at)\gamma^a:I^a\to M, \gamma^a(t)=\gamma(at)γa:Ia→M,γa(t)=γ(at) is an integral curve of Xa=aXX^a=aXXa=aX

For any p∈Mp\in Mp∈M, the integral curve starting at ppp has a maximal interval of existence JpJ_pJp​. It is easy to prove that JpJ_pJp​ must be open.

Denote the maximal curve as

γp:Jp→M\gamma_p:J_p\to M γp​:Jp​→M

We have the following property:

For X∈X(M)X\in \mathfrak{X}(M)X∈X(M), γγp(s)(t)=γp(t+s)\gamma_{\gamma_p(s)}(t)=\gamma_p(t+s)γγp​(s)​(t)=γp​(t+s) if t,s,t+s∈Jpt,s,t+s\in J_pt,s,t+s∈Jp​.

And X∈X(M)X\in \mathfrak{X}(M)X∈X(M) is called a complete vector field if Jp=R,∀p∈MJ_p=\mathbb R,\forall p\in MJp​=R,∀p∈M

Flow

The flow is a mapping on set XXX

Φ:X×R→X\Phi: X\times \mathbb{R} \to X Φ:X×R→X

such that Φ(x,0)=x,Φ(Φ(x,s),t)=Φ(x,s+t)\Phi(x,0)=x,\Phi(\Phi(x,s),t) = \Phi(x,s+t)Φ(x,0)=x,Φ(Φ(x,s),t)=Φ(x,s+t).

In certain situations one might also consider local flows, which are defined only in some subset dom⁡Φ=X\operatorname{dom}\Phi=\mathcal{X}domΦ=X is an open subset of X×RX\times\mathbb RX×R.

We can see that a vector field XXX on MMM induced a flow on MMM.

We have the following theorem stating the smoothness of such flow:

For any X∈Γ∞(TM)X\in \Gamma^{\infty}(TM)X∈Γ∞(TM), the flow Φ:M×R→M\Phi:M\times R\to MΦ:M×R→M is smooth on its domain dom⁡Φ={(p,t)∣p∈M,t∈Jp}\operatorname{dom}\Phi=\{(p,t)|p\in M, t\in J_p\}domΦ={(p,t)∣p∈M,t∈Jp​}.

Proof

By the property of flow, it suffices to prove that Φ\PhiΦ is smooth around any point (p,0)(p,0)(p,0). And then we can transfer the smoothness to any point (q,t)(q,t)(q,t) by the property of flow.

By the fundamental theorem above, there exists a neighborhood UUU of ppp and ϵ>0\epsilon>0ϵ>0 such that Φ(q,t):U×(−ϵ,ϵ)\Phi(q,t): U \times (-\epsilon,\epsilon)Φ(q,t):U×(−ϵ,ϵ) is smooth.
So Φ\PhiΦ is smooth around (p,0)(p,0)(p,0).

If the vector field XXX is complete, then the flow Φ\PhiΦ is defined on the whole M×RM\times \mathbb RM×R.

We call the flow Φ\PhiΦ of a complete vector field XXX the global flow of XXX. Otherwise, we call it a local flow.

Completeness and the induced diffeomorphism

We shall naturally ask, when is a vector field complete?

A sufficient condition is that the vector field has compact support.

We define the support of a vector field X∈X(M)X\in \mathfrak{X}(M)X∈X(M) as:

supp⁡(X)={p∈M∣Xp≠0}‾\operatorname{supp}(X) = \overline{\{p\in M|X_p\neq 0\}} supp(X)={p∈M∣Xp​=0}​

We state the proof idea here:

  • For Xp=0X_p = 0Xp​=0, the integral curve is constant, so it is defined on R\mathbb RR.
  • For Xp≠0X_p \neq 0Xp​=0, then the integral curve γp(t)\gamma_p(t)γp​(t) shall be always in C=supp⁡(X)C=\operatorname{supp}(X)C=supp(X). And there exists a ϵp\epsilon_pϵp​ such that Γ(q,t)\Gamma(q,t)Γ(q,t) is defined on Up×(−ϵp,ϵp)U_p\times (-\epsilon_p,\epsilon_p)Up​×(−ϵp​,ϵp​). Now since CCC is compact, we can cover CCC with finite many UpiU_{p_i}Upi​​, and let ϵ=min⁡ϵpi\epsilon = \min \epsilon_{p_i}ϵ=minϵpi​​. Then for any q∈Cq\in Cq∈C, γq(t)\gamma_q(t)γq​(t) is defined on (−ϵ,ϵ)(-\epsilon,\epsilon)(−ϵ,ϵ). And by proper reparametrization, we can extend the integral curve to the whole R\mathbb RR.

As a corollary, a vector field on a compact manifold is always complete.

Induced Diffeomorphism

Let X∈X(M)X\in \mathfrak{X}(M)X∈X(M) be a complete vector field on MMM, then the flow Φ:M×R→M\Phi:M\times \mathbb R\to MΦ:M×R→M induces a one-parameter group of diffeomorphisms {ϕt:M→M∣t∈R}\{\phi_t:M\to M|t\in \mathbb R\}{ϕt​:M→M∣t∈R} defined as:

ϕt(p)=Φ(p,t)\phi_t(p) = \Phi(p,t) ϕt​(p)=Φ(p,t)

And ϕt\phi_tϕt​ satisfies the following properties:

  • ϕ0=idM\phi_0 = \text{id}_Mϕ0​=idM​
  • ϕs+t=ϕs∘ϕt\phi_{s+t} = \phi_s \circ \phi_tϕs+t​=ϕs​∘ϕt​ for all s,t∈Rs,t\in \mathbb Rs,t∈R.
  • Each ϕt\phi_tϕt​ is a diffeomorphism and ϕt−1=ϕ−t\phi_t^{-1} = \phi_{-t}ϕt−1​=ϕ−t​.

That is to say, a complete vector field on MMM induces a family of diffeomorphisms from MMM to itself.

Dynamical Systems Induced by Vector Fields

Mathematically, a dynamical system is a triple (T,X,Φ)(T,X,\Phi)(T,X,Φ), where XXX is a set called the state space, TTT is a semi-group of transformation parameters called the time set, and Φ\PhiΦ is a mapping from X×TX \times TX×T to XXX that satisfies the properties of flow.

So a complete vector field XXX on a smooth manifold MMM induces a dynamical system (R,M,Φ)(\mathbb R, M, \Phi)(R,M,Φ), where Φ\PhiΦ is the flow of XXX.

Application in Morse Theory

The following theorem is a fundamental result in Morse theory indicating the topological structure of the manifold MMM is determined by the properties of the vector field XXX around the critical points.

Let MMM be a smooth manifold, and f:M→Rf: M \to \mathbb Rf:M→R be a smooth function on MMM. For any a∈Ra\in \mathbb Ra∈R, we define the sublevel set Ma={p∈M∣f(p)≤a}=f−1((−∞,a))M_a = \{p\in M | f(p) \leq a\}=f^{-1}((-\infty,a))Ma​={p∈M∣f(p)≤a}=f−1((−∞,a))

For a<ba<ba<b, assuming that f−1([a,b])f^{-1}([a,b])f−1([a,b]) is compact and ∀c∈[a,b]\forall c\in [a,b]∀c∈[a,b] is a regular value of fff, then there exists a diffeomorphism φ:M→M\varphi:M\to Mφ:M→M such that φ(Ma)=Mb\varphi(M^a)=M^bφ(Ma)=Mb (a deformation retract, more precisely).

Proof

First we embed MMM into a Eulidean space, so a inner product is given in every tangent space TpMT_pMTp​M.

We define a gradient vector field ∇f\nabla f∇f as following:

⟨∇f∣p,Xp⟩=dfp(Xp)=Xp(f),∀Xp∈TpM\langle \nabla f|_p,X_p\rangle = df_p(X_p)= X_p(f), \quad \forall X_p\in T_pM ⟨∇f∣p​,Xp​⟩=dfp​(Xp​)=Xp​(f),∀Xp​∈Tp​M

We take a compact support bump function hhh such that f−1([a,b])⊆supp⁡(h)⊆Uf^{-1}([a,b])\subseteq \operatorname{supp}(h)\subseteq Uf−1([a,b])⊆supp(h)⊆U and UUU is a open set not containing any critical point.

And

X:=h⟨∇f,∇f⟩∇fX:=\frac{h}{\langle \nabla f, \nabla f \rangle} \nabla f X:=⟨∇f,∇f⟩h​∇f

is a compact support vector field on MMM.

Let φ:M×R→M\varphi: M \times \mathbb{R} \to Mφ:M×R→M be the global flow generated by XXX, then

ddtφt∗f(p)=ddtf(φt(p))=⟨∇f,X⟩=h⟨∇f,∇f⟩⟨∇f,∇f⟩=h\frac{d}{dt}\varphi_t^*f(p) = \frac{d}{dt} f(\varphi_t(p)) = \langle \nabla f, X \rangle = \frac{h}{\langle \nabla f, \nabla f \rangle} \langle \nabla f, \nabla f \rangle = h dtd​φt∗​f(p)=dtd​f(φt​(p))=⟨∇f,X⟩=⟨∇f,∇f⟩h​⟨∇f,∇f⟩=h

So we have f(φt(p))=t+f(p)f(\varphi_t(p)) = t + f(p)f(φt​(p))=t+f(p) for any φt(p)∈f−1([a,b])\varphi_t(p)\in f^{-1}([a,b])φt​(p)∈f−1([a,b]).

Thus, the diffeomorphism φb−a\varphi_{b-a}φb−a​ maps MaM^aMa to MbM^bMb.

Lie Derivative

The Lie derivative of a function f∈C∞(M)f\in C^{\infty}(M)f∈C∞(M) with respect to a vector field X∈X(M)X\in \mathfrak{X}(M)X∈X(M) is defined as:

LXf=X(f)=lim⁡t→0f∘φt−ft\mathcal{L}_X f = X(f) = \lim_{t\to 0} \frac{f\circ \varphi_t - f}{t} LX​f=X(f)=t→0lim​tf∘φt​−f​

where φt\varphi_tφt​ is the flow of XXX.

The Lie derivative of a vector field Y∈X(M)Y\in \mathfrak{X}(M)Y∈X(M) with respect to a vector field X∈X(M)X\in \mathfrak{X}(M)X∈X(M) is defined as:

LXY=ddt∣t=0(dφ−t)φt(p)(Yφt(p))=lim⁡t→0(dφ−t)φt(p)(Yφt(p))−Ypt=[X,Y]\mathcal{L}_X Y = \frac{d}{dt}\bigg|_{t=0} (d\varphi_{-t})_{\varphi_t(p)}(Y_{\varphi_t(p)}) = \lim_{t\to 0} \frac{(d\varphi_{-t})_{\varphi_t(p)}(Y_{\varphi_t(p)}) - Y_p}{t} = [X,Y] LX​Y=dtd​​t=0​(dφ−t​)φt​(p)​(Yφt​(p)​)=t→0lim​t(dφ−t​)φt​(p)​(Yφt​(p)​)−Yp​​=[X,Y]

where φt\varphi_tφt​ is the flow of XXX.

The second equality is because for any f∈C∞(U)f\in C^{\infty}(U)f∈C∞(U) defined around ppp:

(dφ−t)φt(p)(Yφt(p))(f)=Yφt(p)(f∘φ−t)=Y(f∘φ−t)∘φt(p)=(φt∗(Y(f∘φ−t)))(p)=(φt∗Yφ−t∗f)(p)\begin{align*} (d\varphi_{-t})_{\varphi_t(p)}(Y_{\varphi_t(p)})(f) &= Y_{\varphi_t(p)}(f\circ \varphi_{-t}) \\ &= Y(f\circ \varphi_{-t})\circ \varphi_t(p) \\ &= (\varphi_t^*(Y(f\circ \varphi_{-t})))(p) \\ &= (\varphi_t^*Y\varphi_{-t}^*f)(p) \end{align*} (dφ−t​)φt​(p)​(Yφt​(p)​)(f)​=Yφt​(p)​(f∘φ−t​)=Y(f∘φ−t​)∘φt​(p)=(φt∗​(Y(f∘φ−t​)))(p)=(φt∗​Yφ−t∗​f)(p)​

And

ddt∣t=0(dφ−t)φt(p)(Yφt(p))f=ddt∣t=0(φt∗Yφ−t∗f)=ddt∣t=0φt∗Yf+Yddt∣t=0φ−t∗f=XYf−YXf=[X,Y]f\begin{align*} \frac{d}{dt}\bigg|_{t=0} (d\varphi_{-t}) _{\varphi_t(p)}(Y_{\varphi_t(p)}) f &= \frac{d}{dt}\bigg|_{t=0} (\varphi_t^*Y\varphi_{-t}^*f) \\ &= \frac{d}{dt}\bigg|_{t=0} \varphi_t^*Yf + Y\frac{d}{dt}\bigg|_{t=0} \varphi_{-t}^*f\\ &= XYf-YXf = [X,Y]f \end{align*} dtd​​t=0​(dφ−t​)φt​(p)​(Yφt​(p)​)f​=dtd​​t=0​(φt∗​Yφ−t∗​f)=dtd​​t=0​φt∗​Yf+Ydtd​​t=0​φ−t∗​f=XYf−YXf=[X,Y]f​

The Lie derivative is a derivation on the Lie algebra X(M)→X(M)\mathfrak{X}(M)\to \mathfrak{X}(M)X(M)→X(M). That is to say, for any X,Y,Z∈X(M)X,Y,Z\in \mathfrak{X}(M)X,Y,Z∈X(M) and a,b∈Ra,b\in \mathbb Ra,b∈R, we have the Leibniz rule:

LX([Y,Z])=[LXY,Z]+[Y,LXZ]L_X([Y,Z]) = [L_X Y, Z] + [Y, L_X Z] LX​([Y,Z])=[LX​Y,Z]+[Y,LX​Z]

Proof

By the Jacobi identity, we have:

LX([Y,Z])=[X,[Y,Z]]=−[Y,[Z,X]]−[Z,[X,Y]]=[[X,Y],Z]+[Y,[X,Z]]=[LXY,Z]+[Y,LXZ]\begin{align*} L_X([Y,Z]) &= [X,[Y,Z]] \\ &= - [Y,[Z,X]] - [Z,[X,Y]] \\ &= [ [X,Y], Z] + [Y, [X,Z]] \\ &= [L_X Y, Z] + [Y, L_X Z] \end{align*} LX​([Y,Z])​=[X,[Y,Z]]=−[Y,[Z,X]]−[Z,[X,Y]]=[[X,Y],Z]+[Y,[X,Z]]=[LX​Y,Z]+[Y,LX​Z]​

So we can see the Jacobi identity as the Leibniz rule of the Lie derivative.

Lie Group

Let GGG be a group, we say GGG is a Lie group if it is a smooth manifold and the group operation μ:G×G→G,(g1,g2)↦g1⋅g2\mu:G\times G\to G, (g_1,g_2)\mapsto g_1\cdot g_2μ:G×G→G,(g1​,g2​)↦g1​⋅g2​ is smooth mappings.

Examples of Lie groups include:

  • Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn with addition as the group operation.
  • Rn∖{0}\mathbb{R}^n\setminus\{0\}Rn∖{0} with multiplication as the group operation.
  • The general linear group GL⁡(n,R)\operatorname{GL}(n,\mathbb{R})GL(n,R), which consists of all invertible n×nn \times nn×n matrices with real entries, with matrix multiplication as the group operation.
  • The special orthogonal group SO⁡(n)\operatorname{SO}(n)SO(n), which consists of all n×nn \times nn×n orthogonal matrices with determinant 1, with matrix multiplication as the group operation.
  • S1\mathbb S^1S1, the circle group, which can be identified with the unit complex numbers under multiplication.
  • S3\mathbb S^3S3, the 3-sphere, which can be identified with unit quaternions under multiplication.

A Lie group must satisfy the following properties:

  • The base space GGG (i.e. the underlying topological space) is orientable.
  • The fundamental group π1(G)\pi_1(G)π1​(G) is a abelian group for a connected Lie group GGG.
  • Every Lie group is parallelizable, i.e., its tangent bundle is trivial TM≅G×RnTM \cong G \times \mathbb{R}^nTM≅G×Rn, where n=dim⁡Gn = \dim Gn=dimG.

Left and Right Multiplication

Assume GGG is a Lie group, for any g∈Gg\in Gg∈G, the left multiplication and right multiplication induce two mappings on GGG:

Lg:G→G,Lg(h)=g⋅hL_g: G \to G, \quad L_g(h) = g\cdot h Lg​:G→G,Lg​(h)=g⋅h

Rg:G→G,Rg(h)=h⋅gR_g : G \to G, \quad R_g(h) = h\cdot g Rg​:G→G,Rg​(h)=h⋅g

Note we can write them as the composition of the group operation and the inclusion map:

Lg=μ∘lg=(ig,idG),Rg=μ∘rg=(idG,ig)L_g = \mu \circ l_g=(i_g, \text{id}_G), \quad R_g = \mu \circ r_g=(\text{id}_G, i_g) Lg​=μ∘lg​=(ig​,idG​),Rg​=μ∘rg​=(idG​,ig​)

where ig:{e}→Gi_g: \{e\} \to Gig​:{e}→G is the inclusion map from the identity element eee to ggg.

And Lg−1=Lg−1,Rg−1=Rg−1L_g^{-1} = L_{g^{-1}}, R_g^{-1} = R_{g^{-1}}Lg−1​=Lg−1​,Rg−1​=Rg−1​.

Thus, LgL_gLg​ and RgR_gRg​ are diffeomorphisms on GGG.

To show the usefulness of left and right multiplication, we leveraged them to prove that every Lie group is parallelizable.

Theorem
Every Lie group GGG is parallelizable, i.e., its tangent bundle is trivial TG≅G×RnTG \cong G \times \mathbb{R}^nTG≅G×Rn, where n=dim⁡Gn = \dim Gn=dimG.

Proof
Consider

Φ:G×TeG→TG(g,v)↦(g,(dLg)e(v))\begin{align*} \Phi: G \times T_eG &\to TG \\ (g,v) &\mapsto (g, (dL_g)_e(v)) \end{align*} Φ:G×Te​G(g,v)​→TG↦(g,(dLg​)e​(v))​

where eee is the identity element of GGG.
It is easy to see that Φ\PhiΦ is a bijection. And since LgL_gLg​ is a diffeomorphism, (dLg)e(dL_g)_e(dLg​)e​ is a linear isomorphism from TeGT_eGTe​G to TgGT_gGTg​G. So Φ\PhiΦ is a diffeomorphism.

Use the same technique, we can also show that the inverse mapping g↦g−1g\mapsto g^{-1}g↦g−1 is a smooth diffeomorphism on GGG.

And the differential of the inverse mapping is given by:

(dι)aXa=−(dLa−1)e(dRa−1)aXa(d\iota)_a X_a = -(dL_{a^{-1}})_e (dR_{a^{-1}})_a X_a (dι)a​Xa​=−(dLa−1​)e​(dRa−1​)a​Xa​

And (dμ)e,e(Xe,Ye)=Xe+Ye,(dι)e(Xe)=−Xe(d\mu)_{e,e}(X_e,Y_e) = X_e+Y_e, (d\iota)_e(X_e) = -X_e(dμ)e,e​(Xe​,Ye​)=Xe​+Ye​,(dι)e​(Xe​)=−Xe​.

Lie Algebra

From the proof above, we see that the tangent space TeGT_eGTe​G determines the structure around any point g∈Gg\in Gg∈G.

So we focus on the structure around the identity element eee of the Lie group GGG.

Definition

Let VVV be a vector space over R\mathbb RR (or any field K\mathbb KK) with a map [⋅,⋅]:V×V→V[\cdot,\cdot]: V \times V \to V[⋅,⋅]:V×V→V satisfying the following properties:

  • Antisymmetry: [X,Y]=−[Y,X][X,Y] = -[Y,X][X,Y]=−[Y,X] for all X,Y∈VX,Y\in VX,Y∈V.
  • Linearity: [aX+bY,Z]=a[X,Z]+b[Y,Z],∀a,b∈R[aX+bY,Z]=a[X,Z]+b[Y,Z],\forall a,b\in \mathbb R[aX+bY,Z]=a[X,Z]+b[Y,Z],∀a,b∈R.
  • Jacobi Identity: [X,[Y,Z]]+[Y,[Z,X]]+[Z,[X,Y]]=0[X,[Y,Z]] + [Y,[Z,X]] + [Z,[X,Y]] = 0[X,[Y,Z]]+[Y,[Z,X]]+[Z,[X,Y]]=0 for all X,Y,Z∈VX,Y,Z\in VX,Y,Z∈V.

Then (V,[⋅,⋅])(V,[\cdot,\cdot])(V,[⋅,⋅]) is called a Lie algebra and the map [⋅,⋅][\cdot,\cdot][⋅,⋅] is called the Lie bracket.

Left Invariant Vector Fields

Assume GGG is a Lie group, Xe∈TeGX_e\in T_eGXe​∈Te​G is a vector in the tangent space at the identity element eee. We can define a vector field X∈X(G)X\in \mathfrak{X}(G)X∈X(G) as follows:

X(g)=(dLg)e(Xe)X(g) = (dL_g)_e(X_e) X(g)=(dLg​)e​(Xe​)

This vector field is called a left invariant vector field because it is invariant under left multiplication, i.e., dLgX(h)=X(gh)dL_g X(h) = X(gh)dLg​X(h)=X(gh) for all g,h∈Gg,h\in Gg,h∈G.

It is obvious that any left invariant vector field is uniquely determined by its value at the identity element eee.

Denote the set of all left invariant vector fields on GGG as g={X∈X(G)∣X(g)=(dLg)e(Xe),∀g∈G}\mathfrak{g} = \{X\in \mathfrak{X}(G)| X(g) = (dL_g)_e(X_e), \forall g\in G\}g={X∈X(G)∣X(g)=(dLg​)e​(Xe​),∀g∈G}.

The set g\mathfrak{g}g is a vector space over R\mathbb RR and g≃TeG\mathfrak{g} \simeq T_eGg≃Te​G, dim⁡g=dim⁡G\dim \mathfrak{g} = \dim Gdimg=dimG.

For any X,Y∈g,g∈GX,Y\in \mathfrak{g}, g\in GX,Y∈g,g∈G, we can verify that:

((dLg)e([X,Y]e))f=[X,Y]e(f∘Lg)=(X(Y(f∘Lg))−Y(X(f∘Lg)))(e)=(XYf−YXf)(g)=[X,Y]gf\begin{align*} ( (dL_g)_e([X,Y]_e) )f &= [X,Y]_e (f\circ L_g) \\ &= (X(Y(f\circ L_g)) - Y(X(f\circ L_g)))(e) \\ &= (XYf-YXf)(g)\\ &= [X,Y]_g f \end{align*} ((dLg​)e​([X,Y]e​))f​=[X,Y]e​(f∘Lg​)=(X(Y(f∘Lg​))−Y(X(f∘Lg​)))(e)=(XYf−YXf)(g)=[X,Y]g​f​

Thus [X,Y][X,Y][X,Y] is also a left invariant vector field.

So g\mathfrak{g}g is a Lie algebra with the Lie bracket induced by the Lie bracket of X(G)\mathfrak{X}(G)X(G), which is called the Lie Algebra on Lie group GGG.

Homomorphism of Lie Groups and Lie Algebras

There are two types of homomorphism, one is the Lie group homomorphism and the other is the Lie algebra homomorphism, which are morphism between Lie group categories and Lie algebra categories respectively.

Let G,HG,HG,H be Lie groups, if smooth mapping ϕ:G→H\phi: G\to Hϕ:G→H is a group homomorphism, we call ϕ\phiϕ a Lie group homomorphism. If ϕ\phiϕ is a diffeomorphism, we call ϕ\phiϕ a Lie group isomorphism.

Let g,h\mathfrak{g,h}g,h be Lie algebras, if a linear mapping L:g→hL:\mathfrak{g}\to \mathfrak{h}L:g→h satisfies L([X,Y])=[L(X),L(Y)]L([X,Y]) = [L(X),L(Y)]L([X,Y])=[L(X),L(Y)] for all X,Y∈gX,Y\in \mathfrak{g}X,Y∈g, we call LLL a Lie algebra homomorphism. If LLL is invertible, we call LLL a Lie algebra isomorphism. Note that if LLL is invertible, then L−1L^{-1}L−1 is also a Lie algebra homomorphism.

Examples

For any Lie group GGG, the conjugation mapping Cg:G→GC_g: G\to GCg​:G→G defined as:

Cg(h)=ghg−1=Lg∘Rg−1(h)C_g(h) = g h g^{-1} = L_g \circ R_{g^{-1}}(h) Cg​(h)=ghg−1=Lg​∘Rg−1​(h)

is a Lie group isomorphism for any g∈Gg\in Gg∈G. The inverse mapping is given by Cg−1C_{g^{-1}}Cg−1​.

For any X∈GL(n,R)X\in GL(n,\mathbb R)X∈GL(n,R), the adjoint mapping Ad⁡X:gl(n,R)→gl(n,R)\operatorname{Ad}_X: \mathfrak{gl}(n,\mathbb R) \to \mathfrak{gl}(n,\mathbb R)AdX​:gl(n,R)→gl(n,R) defined as:

Ad⁡X(Y)=XYX−1\operatorname{Ad}_X(Y) = XYX^{-1} AdX​(Y)=XYX−1

is a Lie group isomorphism. The inverse mapping is given by Ad⁡X−1\operatorname{Ad}_{X^{-1}}AdX−1​.

Induced Lie Algebra Homomorphism

Let ϕ:G→H\phi: G\to Hϕ:G→H be a Lie group homomorphism, then the differential of ϕ\phiϕ at the identity element e∈Ge\in Ge∈G, induced a mapping dϕ:g≃TeG→Tϕ(e)H≃hd\phi: \mathfrak{g} \simeq T_eG \to T_{\phi(e)}H\simeq \mathfrak{h}dϕ:g≃Te​G→Tϕ(e)​H≃h, is a Lie algebra homomorphism from the Lie algebra g\mathfrak{g}g of GGG to the Lie algebra h\mathfrak{h}h of HHH.

To write it more explicitly, for any X∈gX\in \mathfrak{g}X∈g, Xe∈TeGX_e\in T_eGXe​∈Te​G is the value of XXX at eee.

dϕe:TeG→Tϕ(e)HXe↦(dϕ)e(Xe)\begin{align*} d\phi_e: T_eG &\to T_{\phi(e)}H \\ X_e &\mapsto (d\phi)_e(X_e) \end{align*} dϕe​:Te​GXe​​→Tϕ(e)​H↦(dϕ)e​(Xe​)​

dϕ:g→hX↦[h↦dLh(dϕe(Xe))]\begin{align*} d\phi: \mathfrak{g} &\to \mathfrak{h} \\ X &\mapsto [h \mapsto dL_h(d\phi_e(X_e))] \end{align*} dϕ:gX​→h↦[h↦dLh​(dϕe​(Xe​))]​

To see that dϕd\phidϕ is a Lie algebra homomorphism, we need to show that dϕ([X,Y])=[dϕ(X),dϕ(Y)]d\phi([X,Y]) = [d\phi(X), d\phi(Y)]dϕ([X,Y])=[dϕ(X),dϕ(Y)] for any X,Y∈gX,Y\in \mathfrak{g}X,Y∈g.

For any f∈C∞(H)f\in C^{\infty}(H)f∈C∞(H), we have:

(dϕ([X,Y]))ehf=dLeh(dϕe([X,Y]e))f=(dϕe([X,Y]e))(f)=[X,Y]e(f∘ϕ)\begin{align*} (d\phi([X,Y]))_{e_{h}} f &= dL_{e_{h}}(d\phi_e([X,Y]_e)) f \\ &= (d\phi_e([X,Y]_e))(f) \\ &= [X,Y]_e (f\circ \phi) \\ \end{align*} (dϕ([X,Y]))eh​​f​=dLeh​​(dϕe​([X,Y]e​))f=(dϕe​([X,Y]e​))(f)=[X,Y]e​(f∘ϕ)​

[dϕ(X),dϕ(Y)]ehf=(dϕ(X)dϕ(Y)f−dϕ(Y)dϕ(X)f)(eh)=(dϕ(X)(dϕ(Y)f))(eh)−(dϕ(Y)(dϕ(X)f))(eh)=(dϕe(Xe))(dϕ(Y)f)−(dϕe(Ye))(dϕ(X)f)=Xe(dϕ(Y)f∘ϕ)−Ye(dϕ(X)f∘ϕ)\begin{align*} [d\phi(X), d\phi(Y)]_{e_{h}} f &= (d\phi(X) d\phi(Y) f - d\phi(Y) d\phi(X) f)(e_{h}) \\ &= (d\phi(X)(d\phi(Y) f))(e_{h}) - (d\phi(Y)(d\phi(X) f))(e_{h}) \\ &= (d\phi_e(X_e))(d\phi(Y) f) - (d\phi_e(Y_e))(d\phi(X) f) \\ &= X_e (d\phi(Y) f \circ \phi) - Y_e (d\phi(X) f \circ \phi) \\ \end{align*} [dϕ(X),dϕ(Y)]eh​​f​=(dϕ(X)dϕ(Y)f−dϕ(Y)dϕ(X)f)(eh​)=(dϕ(X)(dϕ(Y)f))(eh​)−(dϕ(Y)(dϕ(X)f))(eh​)=(dϕe​(Xe​))(dϕ(Y)f)−(dϕe​(Ye​))(dϕ(X)f)=Xe​(dϕ(Y)f∘ϕ)−Ye​(dϕ(X)f∘ϕ)​

To move on, we need:

Lemma:

(dϕ(X)f)ϕ=X(f∘ϕ)(d\phi(X)f) \phi = X(f\circ \phi) (dϕ(X)f)ϕ=X(f∘ϕ)

Proof:
For any g∈Gg\in Gg∈G, we have:

(dϕ(X)f)ϕ(g)=dϕ(X)∣ϕ(g)f=(dLϕ(g))eH(dϕe(Xe))f=dϕg(dLg)e(Xe)f=dϕgXgf=Xg(f∘ϕ)=X(f∘ϕ)(g)\begin{align*} (d\phi(X)f) \phi(g) &= d\phi(X)|_{\phi(g)} f \\ &= (dL_{\phi(g)})_{e_H}(d\phi_e(X_e)) f \\ &= d\phi_g (dL_g)_e (X_e) f \\ &= d\phi_g X_g f \\ &= X_g (f \circ \phi) \\ &= X(f \circ \phi) (g) \end{align*} (dϕ(X)f)ϕ(g)​=dϕ(X)∣ϕ(g)​f=(dLϕ(g)​)eH​​(dϕe​(Xe​))f=dϕg​(dLg​)e​(Xe​)f=dϕg​Xg​f=Xg​(f∘ϕ)=X(f∘ϕ)(g)​

For the third step, ϕ\phiϕ is a group homomorphism, we know that ϕ(gh)=ϕ(g)ϕ(h)\phi(g h) = \phi(g)\phi(h)ϕ(gh)=ϕ(g)ϕ(h), so Lϕ(g)∘ϕ=ϕ∘LgL_{\phi(g)} \circ \phi = \phi \circ L_gLϕ(g)​∘ϕ=ϕ∘Lg​, differentiating both sides at eee gives us d(Lϕ(g))eH∘dϕe=dϕg∘(dLg)ed(L_{\phi(g)})_{e_H} \circ d\phi_e = d\phi_g \circ (dL_g)_ed(Lϕ(g)​)eH​​∘dϕe​=dϕg​∘(dLg​)e​.

That is to say, the definition of the push forward dϕ(X)d\phi(X)dϕ(X) by the differential of the diffeomorphism ϕ\phiϕ is equivalent to the corresponding vector field induced by the left action dLϕ(⋅)dL_{\phi(\cdot)}dLϕ(⋅)​ on dϕe(Xe)d\phi_e(X_e)dϕe​(Xe​).

So we have:

[dϕ(X),dϕ(Y)]ehf=Xe(dϕ(Y)f∘ϕ)−Ye(dϕ(X)f∘ϕ)=Xe(Y(f∘ϕ))−Ye(X(f∘ϕ))=[X,Y]e(f∘ϕ)=(dϕ([X,Y]))ehf\begin{align*} [d\phi(X), d\phi(Y)]_{e_{h}} f &= X_e (d\phi(Y) f \circ \phi) - Y_e (d\phi(X) f \circ \phi) \\ &= X_e (Y (f\circ \phi)) - Y_e (X (f\circ \phi)) \\ &= [X,Y]_e (f\circ \phi) \\ &= (d\phi([X,Y]))_{e_{h}} f \end{align*} [dϕ(X),dϕ(Y)]eh​​f​=Xe​(dϕ(Y)f∘ϕ)−Ye​(dϕ(X)f∘ϕ)=Xe​(Y(f∘ϕ))−Ye​(X(f∘ϕ))=[X,Y]e​(f∘ϕ)=(dϕ([X,Y]))eh​​f​

The above proof can be summerized as the following:

Step 1: dϕ(X)d\phi(X)dϕ(X) is ϕ\phiϕ-related to XXX.

For X∈gX \in \mathfrak{g}X∈g, dϕ(X)∈hd\phi(X) \in \mathfrak{h}dϕ(X)∈h is left-invariant, and for f∈C∞(H)f \in C^\infty(H)f∈C∞(H), since ϕ(gh)=ϕ(g)ϕ(h)\phi(g h) = \phi(g) \phi(h)ϕ(gh)=ϕ(g)ϕ(h), we have Lϕ(g)∘ϕ=ϕ∘LgL_{\phi(g)} \circ \phi = \phi \circ L_gLϕ(g)​∘ϕ=ϕ∘Lg​.

Differentiating at eee: $ d(L_{\phi(g)}){e_H} \circ d\phi_e = d\phi_g \circ (dL_g)e. $ Thus: $ d\phi(X)|{\phi(g)} f = (dL{\phi(g)}){e_H} (d\phi_e(X_e)) f = d\phi_g ((dL_g)_e X_e) f = X_g (f \circ \phi). $

So, dϕ(X)f∘ϕ=X(f∘ϕ)d\phi(X) f \circ \phi = X (f \circ \phi)dϕ(X)f∘ϕ=X(f∘ϕ), meaning XXX is ϕ\phiϕ-related to dϕ(X)d\phi(X)dϕ(X).

Step 2: Lie Bracket Preservation

If X,Y∈gX, Y \in \mathfrak{g}X,Y∈g are ϕ\phiϕ-related to dϕ(X),dϕ(Y)∈hd\phi(X), d\phi(Y) \in \mathfrak{h}dϕ(X),dϕ(Y)∈h, then [X,Y][X, Y][X,Y] is ϕ\phiϕ-related to [dϕ(X),dϕ(Y)][d\phi(X), d\phi(Y)][dϕ(X),dϕ(Y)].

At g=eg = eg=e: $ [d\phi(X), d\phi(Y)]_{e_H} = d\phi_e ([X, Y]_e). $ Since both are left-invariant, [dϕ(X),dϕ(Y)]=dϕ([X,Y])[d\phi(X), d\phi(Y)] = d\phi([X, Y])[dϕ(X),dϕ(Y)]=dϕ([X,Y]). Linearity of dϕd\phidϕ follows from dϕed\phi_edϕe​.

Thus, dϕd\phidϕ is a Lie algebra homomorphism.
