Exterior Algebra, Differential Forms

Note: we discuss multilinear functions over R\mathbb{R}R-vector spaces, but the theory can be generalized to C\mathbb{C}C-vector spaces or other vector spaces over a field.

Dual Space

Let V,WV,WV,W be a R\mathbb{R}R-vector space, we denote all of the mapping from VVV to WWW as Hom(V,W)\text{Hom}(V,W)Hom(V,W).

The dual space of VVV, denoted as V∨V^{\vee}V∨ or V∗V^*V∗, is the vector space of all linear maps from VVV to R\mathbb{R}R, i.e., V∗=Hom(V,R)V^* = \text{Hom}(V, \mathbb{R})V∗=Hom(V,R).

The elements of the dual space V∗V^*V∗ are called covectors or dual vectors.

The basis of the dual space V∗V^*V∗ is defined as the set of linear functionals that map each basis vector of VVV to R\mathbb{R}R, while mapping all other basis vectors to zero.

To be specific, let VVV be nnn-dimensional vector space, if {e1,e2,…,en}\{e_1, e_2, \ldots, e_n\}{e1​,e2​,…,en​} is a basis of VVV, then the dual basis {α1,α2,…,αn}\{\alpha^1, \alpha^2, \ldots, \alpha^n\}{α1,α2,…,αn} of V∗V^*V∗ is defined by:

αi(ej)=δji\alpha^i(e_j) = \delta^i_j αi(ej​)=δji​

where δji\delta^i_jδji​ is the Kronecker delta.

To show that {α1,α2,…,αn}\{\alpha^1, \alpha^2, \ldots, \alpha^n\}{α1,α2,…,αn} is a basis of V∗V^*V∗, we need to show that it is linearly independent and spans V∗V^*V∗.

Let f∈V∗f \in V^*f∈V∗ be a linear functional. We can express fff in terms of the dual basis as:

f=∑i=1nf(ei)αif = \sum_{i=1}^n f(e_i) \alpha^i f=i=1∑n​f(ei​)αi

where f(ei)f(e_i)f(ei​) are the coefficients of the linear functional fff in the dual basis. This shows that {α1,α2,…,αn}\{\alpha^1, \alpha^2, \ldots, \alpha^n\}{α1,α2,…,αn} spans V∗V^*V∗.

If ∑i=1nciαi=0\sum_{i=1}^n c_i \alpha^i = 0∑i=1n​ci​αi=0 for some coefficients cic_ici​, then for any basis vector ej∈Ve_j \in Vej​∈V, we have:

∑i=1nciαi(ej)=∑i=1nciδji=cj=0\sum_{i=1}^n c_i \alpha^i(e_j) = \sum_{i=1}^n c_i \delta^i_j = c_j = 0 i=1∑n​ci​αi(ej​)=i=1∑n​ci​δji​=cj​=0

for all j=1,2,…,nj = 1, 2, \ldots, nj=1,2,…,n. This implies that all coefficients ci=0c_i = 0ci​=0, showing that the dual basis is linearly independent.

Multilinear function

Let VkV^kVk be the kkk-fold Cartesian product of a vector space VVV, i.e., Vk=V×V×…×V⏟k timesV^k = \underbrace{V \times V \times \ldots \times V}_{k\text{ times}}Vk=k timesV×V×…×V​​ . A multilinear function or kkk-linear function is a function f:Vk→Rf: V^k \to \mathbb{R}f:Vk→R that is linear in each argument separately. It is a type (0,k)(0,k)(0,k) tensor.

One can prove that all multilinear functions on VVV forms a vector space, denoted as Lk(V)L_k(V)Lk​(V) or Mult(Vk;R)\text{Mult}(V^k; \mathbb{R})Mult(Vk;R).

Examples

  1. Dot Product: For a R\mathbb{R}R-vector space VVV with a standard basis {e1,e2,…,en}\{e_1, e_2, \ldots, e_n\}{e1​,e2​,…,en​}, the dot product is a bilinear function f:V2→Rf: V^2 \to \mathbb{R}f:V2→R defined as:

    f(x,y)=∑i=1nxiyif(x,y) = \sum_{i=1}^n x^i y^i f(x,y)=i=1∑n​xiyi

    where x=∑i=1nxieix = \sum_{i=1}^n x^i e_ix=∑i=1n​xiei​ and y=∑i=1nyieiy = \sum_{i=1}^n y^i e_iy=∑i=1n​yiei​ are vectors in VVV.

  2. Determinant: The determinant is a multilinear function f:Vn→Rf: V^n \to \mathbb{R}f:Vn→R defined on the space of n×nn \times nn×n matrices. It is linear in each row (or column) of the matrix.

Let σ∈Sk\sigma\in S_kσ∈Sk​ be a permutation of the indices {1,2,…,k}\{1, 2, \ldots, k\}{1,2,…,k}. The left action of σ\sigmaσ on a multilinear function f:Vk→Rf: V^k \to \mathbb{R}f:Vk→R is defined as:

σf(v1,v2,…,vk)=f(vσ(1),vσ(2),…,vσ(k))\sigma f(v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_k) = f(v_{\sigma(1)}, v_{\sigma(2)}, \ldots, v_{\sigma(k)}) σf(v1​,v2​,…,vk​)=f(vσ(1)​,vσ(2)​,…,vσ(k)​)

A symmetric multilinear function is a multilinear function that is invariant under any permutation of its arguments.

Formally, σf=f\sigma f = fσf=f for any permutation σ∈Sk\sigma\in S_kσ∈Sk​.

An alternating multilinear function is a multilinear function that changes sign when two of its arguments are swapped, or equivalently, changes by a factor of sgn(σ)sgn(\sigma)sgn(σ) when permuted by σ\sigmaσ.

Formally, σf=sgn(σ)f\sigma f = \text{sgn}(\sigma) fσf=sgn(σ)f for any permutation σ∈Sk\sigma\in S_kσ∈Sk​, where sgn(σ)\text{sgn}(\sigma)sgn(σ) is the sign of the permutation.

All symmetric multilinear functions on VVV forms a vector space, denoted as Sk(V)S_k(V)Sk​(V) or Sym(Vk;R)\text{Sym}(V^k; \mathbb{R})Sym(Vk;R).
All alternating multilinear functions on VVV forms a vector space, denoted as Ak(V)A_k(V)Ak​(V) or Alt(Vk;R)\text{Alt}(V^k; \mathbb{R})Alt(Vk;R).

Symmetrizing and Alternating Operators

Let VVV be a vector space and f:Vk→Rf: V^k \to \mathbb{R}f:Vk→R be a multilinear function. We can define the symmetrizing operator and alternating operator on fff.

The symmetrizing operator S:Lk(V)→Sk(V)S: L_k(V) \to S_k(V)S:Lk​(V)→Sk​(V) is defined as:

S(f)(v1,v2,…,vk)=1k!∑σ∈SkσfS(f)(v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_k) = \frac{1}{k!} \sum_{\sigma \in S_k} \sigma f S(f)(v1​,v2​,…,vk​)=k!1​σ∈Sk​∑​σf

The symmetrizing operator takes a multilinear function and produces a symmetric multilinear function by averaging over all permutations of its arguments.

The alternating operator A:Lk(V)→Ak(V)A: L_k(V) \to A_k(V)A:Lk​(V)→Ak​(V) is defined as:

A(f)(v1,v2,…,vk)=1k!∑σ∈Sksgn(σ)σfA(f)(v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_k) = \frac{1}{k!} \sum_{\sigma \in S_k} \text{sgn}(\sigma) \sigma f A(f)(v1​,v2​,…,vk​)=k!1​σ∈Sk​∑​sgn(σ)σf

The alternating operator takes a multilinear function and produces an alternating multilinear function by summing over all permutations of its arguments, weighted by the sign of the permutation.

We shall only prove the alternating operator does produce an alternating multilinear function. The proof for the symmetrizing operator is trivial.

Proof: Let fff be a multilinear function and A(f)A(f)A(f) be the result of the alternating operator. For any permutation τ∈Sk\tau \in S_kτ∈Sk​, we have:

τA(f)=1k!∑σ∈Sksgn(σ)τ∘σf=1k!∑σ∈Sksgn(τ)sgn(τ∘σ)τ∘σf=1k!∑σ′∈Sksgn(σ′)σ′f=sgn(τ)A(f)\begin{align*} \tau A(f) &= \frac{1}{k!} \sum_{\sigma \in S_k} \text{sgn}(\sigma) \tau \circ\sigma f \\ &= \frac{1}{k!} \sum_{\sigma \in S_k} \text{sgn}(\tau) \text{sgn}(\tau \circ \sigma) \tau \circ\sigma f \\ &= \frac{1}{k!} \sum_{\sigma' \in S_k} \text{sgn}(\sigma') \sigma' f \\ &= \text{sgn}(\tau) A(f) \end{align*} τA(f)​=k!1​σ∈Sk​∑​sgn(σ)τ∘σf=k!1​σ∈Sk​∑​sgn(τ)sgn(τ∘σ)τ∘σf=k!1​σ′∈Sk​∑​sgn(σ′)σ′f=sgn(τ)A(f)​

The alternating operator AAA satisfies the following properties:

  1. Linearity: For f1,f2∈Lk(V)f_1, f_2 \in L_k(V)f1​,f2​∈Lk​(V) and r,s∈Rr,s\in \mathbb{R}r,s∈R, we have:

    A(rf1+sf2)=rA(f1)+sA(f2)A(r f_1 + s f_2) = r A(f_1) + s A(f_2) A(rf1​+sf2​)=rA(f1​)+sA(f2​)

  2. A(f⊗A(g))=A(A(f)⊗g)=A(f⊗g)A(f\otimes A(g)) = A(A(f)\otimes g) = A(f\otimes g)A(f⊗A(g))=A(A(f)⊗g)=A(f⊗g)
  3. A∘A=AA\circ A = AA∘A=A

Tensor Product

Let f∈Lk(V)f\in L_k(V)f∈Lk​(V) and g∈Ll(V)g\in L_l(V)g∈Ll​(V) be two multilinear functions on VVV. The tensor product of fff and ggg, denoted as f⊗gf \otimes gf⊗g, is a multilinear function on Vk+lV^{k+l}Vk+l defined as:

(f⊗g)(v1,v2,…,vk+l)=f(v1,v2,…,vk)g(vk+1,vk+2,…,vk+l)(f \otimes g)(v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_{k+l}) = f(v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_k) g(v_{k+1}, v_{k+2}, \ldots, v_{k+l}) (f⊗g)(v1​,v2​,…,vk+l​)=f(v1​,v2​,…,vk​)g(vk+1​,vk+2​,…,vk+l​)

The tensor product satisfies associativity and bilinearity.
Formally, we have:

  1. Associativity: (f⊗g)⊗h=f⊗(g⊗h)(f \otimes g) \otimes h = f \otimes (g \otimes h)(f⊗g)⊗h=f⊗(g⊗h) for any multilinear function h∈Lm(V)h \in L_m(V)h∈Lm​(V).
  2. Bilinearity: For f,f1,f2∈Lk(V)f,f_1,f_2 \in L_k(V)f,f1​,f2​∈Lk​(V) and g,g1,g2∈Ll(V)g,g_1,g_2 \in L_l(V)g,g1​,g2​∈Ll​(V); r,s∈Rr,s\in \mathbb Rr,s∈R, we have:

    (rf1+sf2)⊗g=r(f1⊗g)+s(f2⊗g)(r f_1 + s f_2) \otimes g = r (f_1 \otimes g) + s (f_2 \otimes g) (rf1​+sf2​)⊗g=r(f1​⊗g)+s(f2​⊗g)

    f⊗(rg1+sg2)=r(f⊗g1)+s(f⊗g2)f \otimes (r g_1 + s g_2) = r (f \otimes g_1) + s (f \otimes g_2) f⊗(rg1​+sg2​)=r(f⊗g1​)+s(f⊗g2​)

Example: Let (e1,…,en)(e_1,\ldots,e_n)(e1​,…,en​) be a basis of VVV, (α1,…,αn)(\alpha^1,\ldots,\alpha^n)(α1,…,αn) be the dual basis of V∗V^*V∗. Then the inner product is a bilinear function f:V×V→Rf: V\times V \to \mathbb{R}f:V×V→R defined as:

⟨x,y⟩=∑i=1nxiyi\langle x,y\rangle = \sum_{i=1}^n x^i y^i ⟨x,y⟩=i=1∑n​xiyi

where x=∑i=1nxieix = \sum_{i=1}^n x^i e_ix=∑i=1n​xiei​ and y=∑i=1nyieiy = \sum_{i=1}^n y^i e_iy=∑i=1n​yiei​ are vectors in VVV.

Now, let gij=⟨ei,ej⟩g_{ij}=\langle e_i,e_j\ranglegij​=⟨ei​,ej​⟩, ⟨x,y⟩=∑xiyjgij=∑αi(x)αj(y)gij=∑i,jgij(αi⊗αj)(x,y)\langle x,y\rangle = \sum x^i y^j g_{ij} = \sum \alpha^i(x) \alpha^j(y) g_{ij} = \sum_{i,j} g_{ij} (\alpha^i \otimes \alpha^j)(x,y)⟨x,y⟩=∑xiyjgij​=∑αi(x)αj(y)gij​=∑i,j​gij​(αi⊗αj)(x,y).

So we can write the inner product as a tensor product of the dual basis:

⟨x,y⟩=∑i,jgij(αi⊗αj)(x,y)\langle x,y\rangle = \sum_{i,j} g_{ij} (\alpha^i \otimes \alpha^j)(x,y) ⟨x,y⟩=i,j∑​gij​(αi⊗αj)(x,y)

Wedge Product

The wedge product or exterior product is an operation on alternating multilinear functions that produces a new alternating multilinear function. It is denoted by ∧\wedge∧ and is defined as follows:

For all f∈Ak(V)f \in A_k(V)f∈Ak​(V) and g∈Al(V)g \in A_l(V)g∈Al​(V), the wedge product f∧g∈Ak+l(V)f \wedge g \in A_{k+l}(V)f∧g∈Ak+l​(V) is defined by:

(f∧g)=(k+lk)A(f⊗g)(f \wedge g) = \binom{k+l}{k} A(f\otimes g) (f∧g)=(kk+l​)A(f⊗g)

or equivalently,

(f∧g)(v1,v2,…,vk+l)=1k!l!∑σ∈Sk+lsgn(σ)f(vσ(1),vσ(2),…,vσ(k))g(vσ(k+1),vσ(k+2),…,vσ(k+l))(f \wedge g)(v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_{k+l}) = \frac{1}{k!l!} \sum_{\sigma \in S_{k+l}} \text{sgn}(\sigma) f(v_{\sigma(1)}, v_{\sigma(2)}, \ldots, v_{\sigma(k)}) g(v_{\sigma(k+1)}, v_{\sigma(k+2)}, \ldots, v_{\sigma(k+l)}) (f∧g)(v1​,v2​,…,vk+l​)=k!l!1​σ∈Sk+l​∑​sgn(σ)f(vσ(1)​,vσ(2)​,…,vσ(k)​)g(vσ(k+1)​,vσ(k+2)​,…,vσ(k+l)​)

To avoid division by factorials, we can define the wedge product as sum over sorted permutations:

(f∧g)(v1,v2,…,vk+l)=∑σ∈Sk+lσ(1)<σ(2)<…<σ(k)σ(k+1)<σ(k+2)<…<σ(k+l)sgn(σ)f(vσ(1),vσ(2),…,vσ(k))g(vσ(k+1),vσ(k+2),…,vσ(k+l))\begin{equation*} (f \wedge g)(v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_{k+l}) = \sum_{\substack{\sigma \in S_{k+l} \\ \sigma(1) < \sigma(2) < \ldots < \sigma(k) \\ \sigma(k+1) < \sigma(k+2) < \ldots < \sigma(k+l)}} \text{sgn}(\sigma) f(v_{\sigma(1)}, v_{\sigma(2)}, \ldots, v_{\sigma(k)}) g(v_{\sigma(k+1)}, v_{\sigma(k+2)}, \ldots, v_{\sigma(k+l)}) \end{equation*} (f∧g)(v1​,v2​,…,vk+l​)=σ∈Sk+l​σ(1)<σ(2)<…<σ(k)σ(k+1)<σ(k+2)<…<σ(k+l)​∑​sgn(σ)f(vσ(1)​,vσ(2)​,…,vσ(k)​)g(vσ(k+1)​,vσ(k+2)​,…,vσ(k+l)​)​

Let f∈Ak(V)f \in A_k(V)f∈Ak​(V) and g∈Al(V)g \in A_l(V)g∈Al​(V) be alternating multilinear functions. The wedge product satisfies the following properties:

  1. Bilinearity: It is bilinear on fff and ggg.
  2. Associativity: It is associative, i.e., (f∧g)∧h=f∧(g∧h)(f \wedge g) \wedge h = f \wedge (g \wedge h)(f∧g)∧h=f∧(g∧h) for any alternating multilinear function hhh.
  3. Anticommutativity: It is anticommutative, i.e., f∧g=(−1)klg∧ff \wedge g = (-1)^{kl} g \wedge ff∧g=(−1)klg∧f. Particularly, f∧f=0f \wedge f = 0f∧f=0 when kkk is odd.
  4. c∧f=cfc\wedge f=cfc∧f=cf, ∀c∈R\forall c\in \mathbb R∀c∈R.

Let r∈Nr\in Nr∈N, fi∈Aki(V)f_i\in A_{k_i}(V)fi​∈Aki​​(V) for i=1,2,…,ri=1,2,\ldots,ri=1,2,…,r, the wedge product f1∧f2∧…∧frf_1 \wedge f_2 \wedge \ldots \wedge f_rf1​∧f2​∧…∧fr​ is (k1+…+krk1,…,kr)A(f1⊗f2⊗…⊗fr)\binom{k_1+\ldots+k_r}{k_1,\ldots,k_r} A(f_1\otimes f_2\otimes \ldots \otimes f_r)(k1​,…,kr​k1​+…+kr​​)A(f1​⊗f2​⊗…⊗fr​), where (k1+…+krk1,…,kr)\binom{k_1+\ldots+k_r}{k_1,\ldots,k_r}(k1​,…,kr​k1​+…+kr​​) is the multinomial coefficient.

or equivalently,

(f1∧f2∧…∧fr)(v1,v2,…,vk1+…+kr)=1k1!k2!…kr!∑σ∈Sk1+…+krsgn(σ)f1(vσ(1),vσ(2),…,vσ(k1))f2(vσ(k1+1),vσ(k1+2),…,vσ(k1+k2))…fr(vσ(k1+…+kr−1+1),vσ(k1+…+kr−1+2),…,vσ(k1+…+kr))(f_1 \wedge f_2 \wedge \ldots \wedge f_r)(v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_{k_1+\ldots+k_r}) = \frac{1}{k_1!k_2!\ldots k_r!} \sum_{\sigma \in S_{k_1+\ldots+k_r}} \text{sgn}(\sigma) f_1(v_{\sigma(1)}, v_{\sigma(2)}, \ldots, v_{\sigma(k_1)}) f_2(v_{\sigma(k_1+1)}, v_{\sigma(k_1+2)}, \ldots, v_{\sigma(k_1+k_2)}) \ldots f_r(v_{\sigma(k_1+\ldots+k_{r-1}+1)}, v_{\sigma(k_1+\ldots+k_{r-1}+2)}, \ldots, v_{\sigma(k_1+\ldots+k_r)}) (f1​∧f2​∧…∧fr​)(v1​,v2​,…,vk1​+…+kr​​)=k1​!k2​!…kr​!1​σ∈Sk1​+…+kr​​∑​sgn(σ)f1​(vσ(1)​,vσ(2)​,…,vσ(k1​)​)f2​(vσ(k1​+1)​,vσ(k1​+2)​,…,vσ(k1​+k2​)​)…fr​(vσ(k1​+…+kr−1​+1)​,vσ(k1​+…+kr−1​+2)​,…,vσ(k1​+…+kr​)​)

This shows the associativity directly.

Relation to determinant

Let α1,…,αn∈V∗\alpha^1,\ldots,\alpha^n\in V^*α1,…,αn∈V∗, v1,…,vn∈Vv_1,\ldots,v_n\in Vv1​,…,vn​∈V, then:

(α1∧α2∧…∧αn)(v1,v2,…,vn)=det⁡[(αi(vj))i,j](\alpha^1 \wedge \alpha^2 \wedge \ldots \wedge \alpha^n)(v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_n) = \det[(\alpha^i(v_j))_{i,j}] (α1∧α2∧…∧αn)(v1​,v2​,…,vn​)=det[(αi(vj​))i,j​]

This is the determinant of the matrix formed by evaluating the dual basis vectors on the vectors v1,v2,…,vnv_1, v_2, \ldots, v_nv1​,v2​,…,vn​.

Graded Algebra and Exterior Algebra

Graded Algebra

Let K\mathbb KK be a field, the graded algebra (A,×)(A,\times)(A,×) is a vector space AAA over K\mathbb KK equipped with a direct sum decomposition A=⨁k=0∞AkA = \bigoplus_{k=0}^{\infty} A_kA=⨁k=0∞​Ak​, where each AkA_kAk​ is a vector space of degree kkk. The multiplication operation ×:A×A→A\times: A \times A \to A×:A×A→A satisfies:

×:Ak×Al→Ak+l\times: A_k \times A_l \to A_{k+l} ×:Ak​×Al​→Ak+l​

(A,×)(A,\times)(A,×) is called anticommutative if for all a∈Aka \in A_ka∈Ak​ and b∈Alb \in A_lb∈Al​, ab=(−1)klbaab = (-1)^{kl} baab=(−1)klba.

A homomorphism of graded algebra is an algebra homomorphism that preserves the degree.

Exterior Algebra

The exterior algebra or Grassmann algebra (⋀V,∧)(\bigwedge V, \wedge)(⋀V,∧) is a anticommutative graded algebra defined on a vector space VVV with the wedge product ∧\wedge∧, where ⋀V=⨁k=0∞Ak(V)\bigwedge V = \bigoplus_{k=0}^{\infty} A_k(V)⋀V=⨁k=0∞​Ak​(V). When VVV is finite-dimensional, we can write ⋀V=⨁k=0dim⁡VAk(V)\bigwedge V = \bigoplus_{k=0}^{\dim V} A_k(V)⋀V=⨁k=0dimV​Ak​(V) or ⋀V=⨁k=0n⋀kV\bigwedge V = \bigoplus_{k=0}^{n} \bigwedge ^k V⋀V=⨁k=0n​⋀kV, where n=dim⁡Vn = \dim Vn=dimV.

This is because Ak(V)=0A_k(V) = 0Ak​(V)=0 for k>dim⁡Vk > \dim Vk>dimV, which we shall prove later.

⋀kV\bigwedge^k V⋀kV is called the kkk-th exterior power of VVV.

Basis of LkL_kLk​

Let I=(i1,i2,…,ik)I=(i_1,i_2,\ldots,i_k)I=(i1​,i2​,…,ik​) be a kkk-indices, e1,…,ene_1,\ldots,e_ne1​,…,en​ and α1,…,αn\alpha^1,\ldots,\alpha^nα1,…,αn are the basis of the vector space VVV and its dual V∗V^*V∗ respectively. Denote (ei1,ei2,…,eik)(e_{i_1}, e_{i_2}, \ldots, e_{i_k})(ei1​​,ei2​​,…,eik​​) as eIe_IeI​, and αI=αi1∧αi2∧…∧αik\alpha^I = \alpha^{i_1} \wedge \alpha^{i_2} \wedge \ldots \wedge \alpha^{i_k}αI=αi1​∧αi2​∧…∧αik​. αI(eJ)=δJI\alpha^I(e_J) = \delta^I_JαI(eJ​)=δJI​, where δJI\delta^I_JδJI​ is the generalized Kronecker delta, which is 111 if I=JI=JI=J and 000 otherwise.

Let I=(1≤i1<⋯<ik≤n)I=(1 \leq i_1 < \cdots < i_k \leq n)I=(1≤i1​<⋯<ik​≤n), we claim that {αI}I\{\alpha^I\}_{I}{αI}I​ is a basis of Ak(V)A_k(V)Ak​(V).

The proof is similar to the proof in the dual space section.

Corollary 1: The dimension of Ak(V)A_k(V)Ak​(V) is (nk)\binom{n}{k}(kn​), where n=dim⁡Vn = \dim Vn=dimV.

Corollary 2: The dimension of ⋀V\bigwedge V⋀V is ∑k=0n(nk)=2n\sum_{k=0}^{n} \binom{n}{k} = 2^n∑k=0n​(kn​)=2n, where n=dim⁡Vn = \dim Vn=dimV.

Corollary 3: The dimension of Ak(V)A_k(V)Ak​(V) is 000 for k>dim⁡Vk > \dim Vk>dimV.

Proof: For k>dim⁡Vk > \dim Vk>dimV, the set of indices I=(i1,i2,…,ik)I=(i_1,i_2,\ldots,i_k)I=(i1​,i2​,…,ik​) cannot be chosen such that 1≤i1<i2<…<ik≤n1 \leq i_1 < i_2 < \ldots < i_k \leq n1≤i1​<i2​<…<ik​≤n, hence Ak(V)=0A_k(V) = 0Ak​(V)=0.

Inner Product

Let VVV be a vector space, v∈Vv\in Vv∈V, and ω∈⋀kV\omega \in \bigwedge^k Vω∈⋀kV. The inner product of vvv and ω\omegaω, denoted as ιvω\iota_v \omegaιv​ω, is a linear map ιv:⋀kV→⋀k−1V\iota_v: \bigwedge^k V \to \bigwedge^{k-1} Vιv​:⋀kV→⋀k−1V defined by:

ιv(ω)=∑i=1k(−1)i−1αi(v)α1∧…∧αi^∧…∧αk\iota_v(\omega) = \sum_{i=1}^k (-1)^{i-1} \alpha^i(v) \alpha^{1} \wedge \ldots \wedge \widehat{\alpha^i} \wedge \ldots \wedge \alpha^{k} ιv​(ω)=i=1∑k​(−1)i−1αi(v)α1∧…∧αi∧…∧αk

where αi^\widehat{\alpha^i}αi means that the iii-th term is omitted from the wedge product.

Let α∈⋀kV,β∈⋀lV\alpha \in \bigwedge^k V, \beta \in \bigwedge^l Vα∈⋀kV,β∈⋀lV, the inner product satisfies the following properties:

  1. Nilpotency: ιvιvα=0\iota_v \iota_v \alpha = 0ιv​ιv​α=0 for any v∈Vv \in Vv∈V.
  2. ιv(α∧β)=ιv(α)∧β+(−1)kα∧ιv(β)\iota_v(\alpha \wedge \beta) = \iota_v(\alpha) \wedge \beta + (-1)^k \alpha \wedge \iota_v(\beta)ιv​(α∧β)=ιv​(α)∧β+(−1)kα∧ιv​(β).
  3. Linearity: ιav+bw(α)=aιv(α)+bιw(α)\iota_{av + bw}(\alpha) = a \iota_v(\alpha) + b \iota_w(\alpha)ιav+bw​(α)=aιv​(α)+bιw​(α) for any a,b∈Ra,b \in \mathbb{R}a,b∈R and v,w∈Vv,w \in Vv,w∈V.

The inner product ιv\iota_vιv​ is called the interior product or contraction with respect to the vector vvv. It reduces the degree of the form by 1.

Observe the definition, we see that it just the evaluation of the first argument of the alternating multilinear function ω\omegaω at the vector vvv, and then take the wedge product of the remaining arguments.

ιv(ω)(v1,v2,…,vk−1)=ω(v,v1,v2,…,vk−1)\iota_v(\omega)(v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_{k-1}) = \omega(v, v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_{k-1}) ιv​(ω)(v1​,v2​,…,vk−1​)=ω(v,v1​,v2​,…,vk−1​)

Pullback

Let L:W→VL: W \to VL:W→V be a linear map between vector spaces WWW and VVV. The pullback of exterior forms under LLL, denoted as L∗:⋀kV→⋀kWL^*: \bigwedge^k V \to \bigwedge^k WL∗:⋀kV→⋀kW, is defined by:

L∗(ω)(w1,w2,…,wk)=ω(L(w1),L(w2),…,L(wk))L^*(\omega)(w_1, w_2, \ldots, w_k) = \omega(L(w_1), L(w_2), \ldots, L(w_k)) L∗(ω)(w1​,w2​,…,wk​)=ω(L(w1​),L(w2​),…,L(wk​))

for all w1,w2,…,wk∈W∗w_1, w_2, \ldots, w_k \in W^*w1​,w2​,…,wk​∈W∗.

The pullback satisfies the following properties:

  1. L∗(α∧β)=L∗(α)∧L∗(β)L^*(\alpha \wedge \beta) = L^*(\alpha) \wedge L^*(\beta)L∗(α∧β)=L∗(α)∧L∗(β)
  2. ιw(L∗(α))=L∗(ιL(w)(α))\iota_w(L^*(\alpha)) = L^*(\iota_{L(w)}(\alpha))ιw​(L∗(α))=L∗(ιL(w)​(α)).

Differential Forms

We have defined the exterior algebra ⋀V\bigwedge V⋀V and the wedge product ∧\wedge∧ on an abstract vector space VVV. Now we can define differential forms on a manifold MMM, where VVV is the tangent space TpMT_pMTp​M at a point p∈Mp \in Mp∈M.

Cotangent Space and Cotangent Bundle

The cotangent space Tp∗MT^*_pMTp∗​M at a point p∈Mp \in Mp∈M is the dual space of the tangent space TpMT_pMTp​M. It consists of all linear functionals on TpMT_pMTp​M. Elements of the cotangent space are called covectors or differential 1-forms.

The cotangent space Tp∗MT^*_pMTp∗​M is a vector space of dimension nnn, where nnn is the dimension of the manifold MMM.

The cotangent bundle T∗MT^*MT∗M is the disjoint union of all cotangent spaces at each point in MMM:

T∗M=⋃p∈MTp∗M={(p,ωp):p∈M,ωp∈Tp∗M}T^*M = \bigcup_{p \in M} T^*_pM = \{(p, \omega_p) : p \in M, \omega_p \in T^*_pM\} T∗M=p∈M⋃​Tp∗​M={(p,ωp​):p∈M,ωp​∈Tp∗​M}

The cotangent bundle T∗MT^*MT∗M is a manifold of dimension 2n2n2n.

Local coordinates on the cotangent bundle can be defined as (x1,x2,…,xn,ω1,ω2,…,ωn)(x^1, x^2, \ldots, x^n, \omega_1, \omega_2, \ldots, \omega_n)(x1,x2,…,xn,ω1​,ω2​,…,ωn​), where (x1,x2,…,xn)(x^1, x^2, \ldots, x^n)(x1,x2,…,xn) are local coordinates on MMM and (ω1,ω2,…,ωn)(\omega_1, \omega_2, \ldots, \omega_n)(ω1​,ω2​,…,ωn​) are the components of a covector in the cotangent space with respect to the dual basis {dx1,dx2,…,dxn}\{dx^1, dx^2, \ldots, dx^n\}{dx1,dx2,…,dxn}.

Differential kkk-Forms

Let MMM be a smooth manifold of dimension nnn. A differential kkk-form on MMM is a smooth section of the kkk-th exterior power of the cotangent bundle, denoted as ⋀kT∗M\bigwedge^k T^*M⋀kT∗M.

In other words, a differential kkk-form on a open subset U⊆MU \subseteq MU⊆M is a mapping $$ \omega: U \to \bigwedge^k T^*M $$ that assigns to each point p∈Up \in Up∈U an alternating multilinear function ω(p):TpMk→R\omega(p): T_pM^k \to \mathbb{R}ω(p):Tp​Mk→R and ω∈Ak(TpM)\omega \in A_k(T_pM)ω∈Ak​(Tp​M) for all p∈Up \in Up∈U.

Let {e1=∂∂x1∣p,e2=∂∂x2∣p,…,en=∂∂xn∣p}\{e_1 = \left.\frac{\partial}{\partial x^1}\right|_p, e_2 = \left.\frac{\partial}{\partial x^2}\right|_p, \ldots, e_n = \left.\frac{\partial}{\partial x^n}\right|_p\}{e1​=∂x1∂​​p​,e2​=∂x2∂​​p​,…,en​=∂xn∂​​p​} be a basis of TpMT_pMTp​M. The corresponding dual basis of Tp∗MT^*_pMTp∗​M is {dx1,dx2,…,dxn}\{dx^1, dx^2, \ldots, dx^n\}{dx1,dx2,…,dxn}, where dxi(ej)=δjidx^i(e_j) = \delta^i_jdxi(ej​)=δji​.

A basis of Ak(TpM)A_k(T_pM)Ak​(Tp​M) is then given by {dxI}I\{dx^I\}_{I}{dxI}I​, where I=(i1,i2,…,ik)I = (i_1, i_2, \ldots, i_k)I=(i1​,i2​,…,ik​) is a kkk-tuple of indices with 1≤i1<i2<…<ik≤n1 \leq i_1 < i_2 < \ldots < i_k \leq n1≤i1​<i2​<…<ik​≤n, and dxIdx^IdxI denotes the wedge product dxi1∧dxi2∧…∧dxikdx^{i_1} \wedge dx^{i_2} \wedge \ldots \wedge dx^{i_k}dxi1​∧dxi2​∧…∧dxik​.

Therefore, a differential kkk-form ω\omegaω can be expressed in local coordinates as:

ω=∑IfIdxI\omega = \sum_{I} f_I dx^I ω=I∑​fI​dxI

where fI:U→Rf_I: U \to \mathbb{R}fI​:U→R are functions on UUU.

A differential kkk-form ω\omegaω is called smooth if all the functions fIf_IfI​ are smooth functions on UUU.

Let Ωk(M)=Γ∞(⋀kT∗M)\Omega^k(M)=\Gamma^{\infty}(\bigwedge^k T^*M)Ωk(M)=Γ∞(⋀kT∗M) be the space of all smooth differential kkk-forms on a manifold MMM. It is a vector space over R\mathbb{R}R.

The wedge product of two differential forms ω1∈Ωk(M)\omega_1 \in \Omega^k(M)ω1​∈Ωk(M) and ω2∈Ωl(M)\omega_2 \in \Omega^l(M)ω2​∈Ωl(M) is pointwise defined as:

(ω1∧ω2)(p)=ω1(p)∧ω2(p)=∑I,JfI(p)gJ(p)dxI∧dxJ(\omega_1 \wedge \omega_2)(p) = \omega_1(p) \wedge \omega_2(p) = \sum_{I,J} f_I(p) g_J(p) dx^I \wedge dx^J (ω1​∧ω2​)(p)=ω1​(p)∧ω2​(p)=I,J∑​fI​(p)gJ​(p)dxI∧dxJ

where fIf_IfI​ and gJg_JgJ​ are the coefficients of ω1\omega_1ω1​ and ω2\omega_2ω2​ in local coordinates, respectively. Note that if III and JJJ are such that I∩J≠∅I \cap J \neq \emptysetI∩J=∅, then dxI∧dxJ=0dx^I \wedge dx^J = 0dxI∧dxJ=0 due to the anticommutativity of the wedge product.
The wedge product of differential forms is bilinear and associative, and it satisfies the anticommutativity property:

ω1∧ω2=(−1)klω2∧ω1\omega_1 \wedge \omega_2 = (-1)^{kl} \omega_2 \wedge \omega_1 ω1​∧ω2​=(−1)klω2​∧ω1​

Let Ω∗(M)=⨁k=0nΩk(M)\Omega^*(M) = \bigoplus_{k=0}^n \Omega^k(M)Ω∗(M)=⨁k=0n​Ωk(M) be the space of all smooth differential forms on MMM. It is a graded algebra with respect to the wedge product ∧\wedge∧.

Coordinate Functions and Their Differentials

Let (U,x)=(U,x1,…,xn)(U, x) = (U, x^1, \ldots, x^n)(U,x)=(U,x1,…,xn) be a coordinate chart on a smooth manifold MMM of dimension nnn. The coordinate functions xi:U→Rx^i: U \to \mathbb{R}xi:U→R are smooth functions that assign to each point p∈Up \in Up∈U its iii-th coordinate xi(p)x^i(p)xi(p).

The coordinate 1-forms dxidx^idxi are smooth sections of the cotangent bundle, each dxi:U→T∗Mdx^i: U \to T^*Mdxi:U→T∗M satisfies $$\pi \circ dx^i = \text{id}_U$$
where π:T∗M→M\pi: T^*M \to Mπ:T∗M→M is the bundle projection.

We have dxi∣p:TpM→Rdx^i|_p: T_pM \to \mathbb{R}dxi∣p​:Tp​M→R defined by dxi∣p(v)=v(xi(p))dx^i|_p(v) = v(x^i(p))dxi∣p​(v)=v(xi(p)) for any tangent vector v∈TpMv \in T_pMv∈Tp​M. The coordinate 1-forms satisfy the dual basis property: $$\left.dx^i\right|_p\left(\left.\frac{\partial}{\partial x^j}\right|_p\right) = \delta^i_j$$
making {dx1∣p,…,dxn∣p}\{dx^1|_p, \ldots, dx^n|_p\}{dx1∣p​,…,dxn∣p​} the dual basis of Tp∗MT_p^*MTp∗​M corresponding to the coordinate basis {∂∂x1∣p,…,∂∂xn∣p}\{\frac{\partial}{\partial x^1}|_p, \ldots, \frac{\partial}{\partial x^n}|_p\}{∂x1∂​∣p​,…,∂xn∂​∣p​} of TpMT_pMTp​M.

Any differential kkk-form on UUU can be uniquely expressed as ω=∑∣I∣=kfI dxI\omega = \sum_{|I|=k} f_I \, dx^Iω=∑∣I∣=k​fI​dxI, where I=(i1,…,ik)I = (i_1, \ldots, i_k)I=(i1​,…,ik​) with 1≤i1<⋯<ik≤n1 \leq i_1 < \cdots < i_k \leq n1≤i1​<⋯<ik​≤n, dxI=dxi1∧⋯∧dxikdx^I = dx^{i_1} \wedge \cdots \wedge dx^{i_k}dxI=dxi1​∧⋯∧dxik​, and fI:U→Rf_I: U \to \mathbb{R}fI​:U→R are smooth functions.

Pullback of Differential Forms

Let F:M→NF: M \to NF:M→N be a smooth map between manifolds, and let ω∈Ωk(N)\omega \in \Omega^k(N)ω∈Ωk(N) be a differential kkk-form on NNN. The pullback of ω\omegaω by FFF, denoted as F∗ωF^*\omegaF∗ω, is a differential kkk-form on MMM defined by:

(F∗ω)(p)(v1,v2,…,vk)=ω(F(p))(dFp(v1),dFp(v2),…,dFp(vk))(F^*\omega)(p)(v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_k) = \omega(F(p))(dF_p(v_1), dF_p(v_2), \ldots, dF_p(v_k)) (F∗ω)(p)(v1​,v2​,…,vk​)=ω(F(p))(dFp​(v1​),dFp​(v2​),…,dFp​(vk​))

where dFp:TpM→TF(p)NdF_p: T_pM \to T_{F(p)}NdFp​:Tp​M→TF(p)​N is the differential of FFF at the point ppp.

Local Coordinate Expression

Let (U,x1,…,xm)(U, x^1, \ldots, x^m)(U,x1,…,xm) and (V,y1,…,yn)(V, y^1, \ldots, y^n)(V,y1,…,yn) be coordinate charts on MMM and NNN respectively, with F(U)⊆VF(U) \subseteq VF(U)⊆V.

Let F:M→NF: M \to NF:M→N have local coordinate representation Fi=yi∘F∘x−1F^i = y^i \circ F \circ x^{-1}Fi=yi∘F∘x−1, where (x1,…,xm)(x^1, \ldots, x^m)(x1,…,xm) are coordinates on MMM and (y1,…,yn)(y^1, \ldots, y^n)(y1,…,yn) are coordinates on NNN.

If ω\omegaω has the local expression:

ω=∑∣I∣=kfI dyI\omega = \sum_{|I|=k} f_I \, dy^I ω=∣I∣=k∑​fI​dyI

where fI:V→Rf_I: V \to \mathbb{R}fI​:V→R are smooth functions.

Then the pullback F∗ωF^*\omegaF∗ω has the expression:

F∗ω=∑∣I∣=k(fI∘F) F∗(dyI)=∑∣I∣=k(fI∘F) d(yi1∘F)∧⋯∧d(yik∘F)\begin{align*} F^*\omega &= \sum_{|I|=k} (f_I \circ F) \, F^*(dy^I) \\ &= \sum_{|I|=k} (f_I \circ F) \, d(y^{i_1} \circ F) \wedge \cdots \wedge d(y^{i_k} \circ F) \end{align*} F∗ω​=∣I∣=k∑​(fI​∘F)F∗(dyI)=∣I∣=k∑​(fI​∘F)d(yi1​∘F)∧⋯∧d(yik​∘F)​

Note:

d(yij∘F)=d(Fij∘x)=∑l=1m∂Fij∂xldxld(y^{i_j} \circ F) = d(F^{i_j} \circ x) = \sum_{l=1}^m \frac{\partial F^{i_j}}{\partial x^l} dx^l d(yij​∘F)=d(Fij​∘x)=l=1∑m​∂xl∂Fij​​dxl

Therefore:

F∗ω=∑∣I∣=k(fI∘F) (∑l1=1m∂Fi1∂xl1dxl1)∧⋯∧(∑lk=1m∂Fik∂xlkdxlk)F^*\omega = \sum_{|I|=k} (f_I \circ F) \, \left(\sum_{l_1=1}^m \frac{\partial F^{i_1}}{\partial x^{l_1}} dx^{l_1}\right) \wedge \cdots \wedge \left(\sum_{l_k=1}^m \frac{\partial F^{i_k}}{\partial x^{l_k}} dx^{l_k}\right) F∗ω=∣I∣=k∑​(fI​∘F)(l1​=1∑m​∂xl1​∂Fi1​​dxl1​)∧⋯∧(lk​=1∑m​∂xlk​∂Fik​​dxlk​)

Properties of Pullback

The pullback operation satisfies the following important properties:

  1. Linearity: F∗(aω1+bω2)=aF∗ω1+bF∗ω2F^*(a\omega_1 + b\omega_2) = aF^*\omega_1 + bF^*\omega_2F∗(aω1​+bω2​)=aF∗ω1​+bF∗ω2​ for a,b∈Ra,b \in \mathbb{R}a,b∈R

  2. Preservation of wedge product:

    F∗(ω1∧ω2)=F∗ω1∧F∗ω2F^*(\omega_1 \wedge \omega_2) = F^*\omega_1 \wedge F^*\omega_2 F∗(ω1​∧ω2​)=F∗ω1​∧F∗ω2​

  3. Functoriality: If G:L→MG: L \to MG:L→M and F:M→NF: M \to NF:M→N are smooth maps, then:

    (F∘G)∗=G∗∘F∗(F \circ G)^* = G^* \circ F^* (F∘G)∗=G∗∘F∗

  4. Identity: (idM)∗=idΩ∗(M)(\text{id}_M)^* = \text{id}_{\Omega^*(M)}(idM​)∗=idΩ∗(M)​

Exterior Derivative

The Exterior Derivative is an operator d:Ωk(M)→Ωk+1(M)d: \Omega^k(M) \to \Omega^{k+1}(M)d:Ωk(M)→Ωk+1(M) that generalizes the concept of differentiation to differential forms. It is defined as follows:

dω=∑∣I∣=k(∑j=1n∂fI∂xj)dxj∧dxId\omega = \sum_{|I|=k} \left( \sum_{j=1}^n \frac{\partial f_I}{\partial x^j} \right) dx^j \wedge dx^I dω=∣I∣=k∑​(j=1∑n​∂xj∂fI​​)dxj∧dxI

where ω=∑∣I∣=kfI dxI\omega = \sum_{|I|=k} f_I \, dx^Iω=∑∣I∣=k​fI​dxI is a differential kkk-form on MMM, and dxI=dxi1∧⋯∧dxikdx^I = dx^{i_1} \wedge \cdots \wedge dx^{i_k}dxI=dxi1​∧⋯∧dxik​ for I=(i1,…,ik)I = (i_1, \ldots, i_k)I=(i1​,…,ik​).

It can be naturally extended to the exterior algebra ⋀∗(M)\bigwedge^*(M)⋀∗(M) as follows:

d(ω)=∑k=0ndωkd(\omega) = \sum_{k=0}^{n} d\omega_k d(ω)=k=0∑n​dωk​

where ω=∑k=0nωk\omega = \sum_{k=0}^{n} \omega_kω=∑k=0n​ωk​ and ωk∈Ωk(M)\omega_k \in \Omega^k(M)ωk​∈Ωk(M).

The exterior derivative satisfies the following properties:

  1. Linearity: d(aω1+bω2)=adω1+bdω2d(a\omega_1 + b\omega_2) = a d\omega_1 + b d\omega_2d(aω1​+bω2​)=adω1​+bdω2​ for a,b∈Ra,b \in \mathbb{R}a,b∈R.
  2. Nilpotency: d2=0d^2 = 0d2=0, i.e., d(dω)=0d(d\omega) = 0d(dω)=0 for any differential form ω\omegaω.
  3. Antiderivation Property: d(ω1∧ω2)=dω1∧ω2+(−1)kω1∧dω2d(\omega_1 \wedge \omega_2) = d\omega_1 \wedge \omega_2 + (-1)^k \omega_1 \wedge d\omega_2d(ω1​∧ω2​)=dω1​∧ω2​+(−1)kω1​∧dω2​ for ω1∈Ωk(M)\omega_1 \in \Omega^k(M)ω1​∈Ωk(M) and ω2∈Ωl(M)\omega_2 \in \Omega^l(M)ω2​∈Ωl(M).
  4. Pullback Compatibility: For any smooth map F:M→NF: M \to NF:M→N, we have $F^(d\omega) = d(F^\omega) $. One can verify this property using local coordinates and chain rules.
  5. Vanishing of Top Forms: dω=0d\omega = 0dω=0 if ω∈Ωn(M)\omega\in \Omega^n(M)ω∈Ωn(M), where n=dim⁡Mn = \dim Mn=dimM.

We only prove the nilpotency here:

Proof:

Only to prove ω∈Ωk(M)\omega\in \Omega^k(M)ω∈Ωk(M), ω=∑∣I∣=kαIdxI\omega = \sum_{|I|=k} \alpha^{I} dx^{I}ω=∑∣I∣=k​αIdxI

dω=∑∣I∣=k∑i∈[n]∂αI∂xidxi∧dxId(dω)=∑i,j∈[n]∑∣I∣=k∂2αI∂xi∂xjdxi∧dxj∧dxI=∑1≤i<j≤n∑∣I∣=k(∂2αI∂xi∂xj−∂2αI∂xj∂xi)dxi∧dxj∧dxI=0\begin{align*} d \omega &= \sum_{|I|=k}\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{\partial \alpha^I}{\partial x^i}d x^i \wedge dx^I\\ d(d\omega) &= \sum_{i,j\in [n]}\sum_{|I|=k} \frac{\partial^2 \alpha^I}{\partial x^i\partial x^j} d x^i \wedge d x^j \wedge d x^I \\ &= \sum_{1\leq i<j\leq n} \sum_{|I|=k}\left ( \frac{\partial^2 \alpha^I}{\partial x^i\partial x^j} - \frac{\partial^2 \alpha^I}{\partial x^j\partial x^i} \right ) d x^i \wedge d x^j \wedge d x^I \\ &= 0 \end{align*} dωd(dω)​=∣I∣=k∑​i∈[n]∑​∂xi∂αI​dxi∧dxI=i,j∈[n]∑​∣I∣=k∑​∂xi∂xj∂2αI​dxi∧dxj∧dxI=1≤i<j≤n∑​∣I∣=k∑​(∂xi∂xj∂2αI​−∂xj∂xi∂2αI​)dxi∧dxj∧dxI=0​

since mixed partial derivatives commute for smooth functions.

Lie Derivative on Differential Forms

The Lie derivative of a differential form ω∈Ωk(M)\omega \in \Omega^k(M)ω∈Ωk(M) with respect to a vector field XXX is defined as:

LXω=ddt∣t=0ϕt∗ω\mathcal{L}_X \omega = \frac{d}{dt} \bigg|_{t=0} \phi_t^* \omega LX​ω=dtd​​t=0​ϕt∗​ω

where ϕt\phi_tϕt​ is the flow of the vector field XXX at time ttt.

The Lie derivative satisfy the following property:

  1. dLXω=LXdωd\mathcal L_X \omega=\mathcal L_X d\omegadLX​ω=LX​dω
  2. $\mathcal L_X(\omega \wedge \eta)=\mathcal L_X \omega \wedge \eta + \omega \wedge \mathcal L_X\eta $
  3. L[X1,X2]ω=LX1LX2ω−LX2LX1ω\mathcal L_{[X_1,X_2]} \omega = \mathcal L_{X_1}\mathcal L_{X_2}\omega - \mathcal L_{X_2}\mathcal L_{X_1}\omegaL[X1​,X2​]​ω=LX1​​LX2​​ω−LX2​​LX1​​ω
  4. (LXω)(X1,⋯ ,Xk)=LX(ω(X1,⋯ ,Xk))−∑iω(X1,⋯ ,LXXi,⋯ ,Xk)(\mathcal L_X{\omega})(X_1,\cdots,X_k)=\mathcal L_X(\omega(X_1,\cdots,X_k))-\sum_i\omega(X_1,\cdots,\mathcal L_X X_i,\cdots,X_k)(LX​ω)(X1​,⋯,Xk​)=LX​(ω(X1​,⋯,Xk​))−∑i​ω(X1​,⋯,LX​Xi​,⋯,Xk​)
  5. Cartan’s Magic Formula

LXω=dιXω+ιXdωL_{X}\omega=d\iota_X\omega + \iota_Xd\omega LX​ω=dιX​ω+ιX​dω

Proof

  1. dLXω=d(ddt∣t=0ϕt∗ω)=ddt∣t=0d(ϕt∗ω)=ddt∣t=0ϕt∗(dω)=LXdωd\mathcal L_X \omega = d\left(\frac{d}{dt} \bigg|_{t=0} \phi_t^* \omega \right)= \frac{d}{dt} \bigg|_{t=0} d(\phi_t^* \omega) = \frac{d}{dt} \bigg|_{t=0} \phi_t^* (d\omega) = \mathcal L_X d\omegadLX​ω=d(dtd​​t=0​ϕt∗​ω)=dtd​​t=0​d(ϕt∗​ω)=dtd​​t=0​ϕt∗​(dω)=LX​dω
  2. LX(ω∧η)=ddt∣t=0ϕt∗(ω∧η)=ddt∣t=0(ϕt∗ω∧ϕt∗η)=ddt∣t=0(ϕt∗ω)∧η+ω∧ddt∣t=0(ϕt∗η)=LXω∧η+ω∧LXη\mathcal L_X(\omega \wedge \eta) = \frac{d}{dt} \bigg|_{t=0} \phi_t^* (\omega \wedge \eta) = \frac{d}{dt} \bigg|_{t=0} (\phi_t^* \omega \wedge \phi_t^* \eta) = \frac{d}{dt}\bigg|_{t=0} (\phi_t^*\omega)\wedge \eta+\omega\wedge\frac{d}{dt}\bigg|_{t=0}(\phi_t^*\eta) = \mathcal L_X \omega \wedge \eta + \omega \wedge \mathcal L_X\etaLX​(ω∧η)=dtd​​t=0​ϕt∗​(ω∧η)=dtd​​t=0​(ϕt∗​ω∧ϕt∗​η)=dtd​​t=0​(ϕt∗​ω)∧η+ω∧dtd​​t=0​(ϕt∗​η)=LX​ω∧η+ω∧LX​η
  3. Use (5).
  4. Do induction as (5).
  5. For the 000-form and 111-form, it is trivial proved to be true. Then inductively prove by decomposing it on local coordinates.
    Let ω\omegaω be a kkk-form. Locally, we have:

ω=fdx1∧⋯∧dxn=dx1∧ω1\omega=f dx^1\wedge \cdots \wedge dx^n=dx^1\wedge \omega_1 ω=fdx1∧⋯∧dxn=dx1∧ω1​

LXω=LX(dx1)∧ω1+dx1∧LXω1=[ιXd(dx1)+d(ιXdx1)]∧ω1+dx1∧[ιXdω1+d(ιXω1)]\begin{align*} \mathcal L_X \omega &= \mathcal L_X (dx^1) \wedge \omega_1 + dx^1 \wedge \mathcal L_X\omega_1\\ &=[\iota_X d(dx^1)+d(\iota_X dx^1)]\wedge \omega_1+dx^1\wedge [\iota_X d\omega_1+ d(\iota_X \omega_1)] \end{align*} LX​ω​=LX​(dx1)∧ω1​+dx1∧LX​ω1​=[ιX​d(dx1)+d(ιX​dx1)]∧ω1​+dx1∧[ιX​dω1​+d(ιX​ω1​)]​

dιXω+ιXdω=dιX(dx1∧ω1)+ιX(−dx1∧dω1)=d((ιXdx1)∧ω1−dx1∧ιXω1)−(ιXdx1)∧dω1+dx1∧ιXdω1=d(ιXdx1)∧ω1+(ιXdx1)∧dω1+dx1∧d(ιXω1)−(ιXdx1)∧dω1+dx1∧ιXdω1=d(ιXdx1)∧ω1+dx1∧d(ιXω1)+dx1∧ιXdω1=d(ιXdx1)∧ω1+dx1∧[ιXdω1+d(ιXω1)]=LXω\begin{align*} d\iota_X \omega + \iota_X d\omega &= d\iota_X(dx^1\wedge \omega_1) + \iota_X (-dx^1\wedge d\omega_1)\\ &=d((\iota_Xdx^1)\wedge \omega_1-dx^1\wedge \iota_X \omega_1) -(\iota_X dx^1)\wedge d\omega_1 + dx^1\wedge\iota_X d\omega_1\\ &=d(\iota_X dx^1)\wedge \omega_1+(\iota_Xdx^1)\wedge d\omega_1+dx^1\wedge d(\iota_X\omega_1) -(\iota_X dx^1)\wedge d\omega_1 + dx^1\wedge\iota_X d\omega_1\\ &=d(\iota_X dx^1)\wedge \omega_1+dx^1\wedge d(\iota_X\omega_1) + dx^1\wedge\iota_X d\omega_1\\ &=d(\iota_X dx^1)\wedge \omega_1+dx^1\wedge [\iota_X d\omega_1+d(\iota_X \omega_1)]\\ &=\mathcal L_X \omega \end{align*} dιX​ω+ιX​dω​=dιX​(dx1∧ω1​)+ιX​(−dx1∧dω1​)=d((ιX​dx1)∧ω1​−dx1∧ιX​ω1​)−(ιX​dx1)∧dω1​+dx1∧ιX​dω1​=d(ιX​dx1)∧ω1​+(ιX​dx1)∧dω1​+dx1∧d(ιX​ω1​)−(ιX​dx1)∧dω1​+dx1∧ιX​dω1​=d(ιX​dx1)∧ω1​+dx1∧d(ιX​ω1​)+dx1∧ιX​dω1​=d(ιX​dx1)∧ω1​+dx1∧[ιX​dω1​+d(ιX​ω1​)]=LX​ω​

Integration of Differential Forms

Highest Degree Forms

Let MMM be a smooth manifold of dimension nnn. The highest degree differential form on MMM is a differential nnn-form, denoted as ω∈Ωn(M)\omega \in \Omega^n(M)ω∈Ωn(M). It can be expressed in local coordinates (U,x)(U,x)(U,x) as:

ω=f dx1∧dx2∧…∧dxn\omega = f \, dx^1 \wedge dx^2 \wedge \ldots \wedge dx^n ω=fdx1∧dx2∧…∧dxn

where f:M→Rf: M \to \mathbb{R}f:M→R is a smooth function and {dx1,dx2,…,dxn}\{dx^1, dx^2, \ldots, dx^n\}{dx1,dx2,…,dxn} is the basis of the cotangent space at each point in MMM.

If we change the local coordinates to (y1,y2,…,yn)(y^1, y^2, \ldots, y^n)(y1,y2,…,yn) by the pullback map ϕ:V→U\phi: V \to Uϕ:V→U, y=ϕ∗x=x∘ϕy=\phi^*x = x\circ \phiy=ϕ∗x=x∘ϕ, then the highest degree form transforms as:

ϕ∗(dx1∧dx2∧…∧dxn)=det⁡(∂yi∂xj)dy1∧dy2∧…∧dyn\phi^*(dx^1 \wedge dx^2 \wedge \ldots \wedge dx^n) = \det\left(\frac{\partial y^i}{\partial x^j}\right) dy^1 \wedge dy^2 \wedge \ldots \wedge dy^n ϕ∗(dx1∧dx2∧…∧dxn)=det(∂xj∂yi​)dy1∧dy2∧…∧dyn

We can define the integral of a highest degree form over UUU as:

∫Uω=∫Uf dx1∧dx2∧…∧dxn=∫Ufdx1dx2⋯dxn\int_U \omega = \int_U f \, dx^1 \wedge dx^2 \wedge \ldots \wedge dx^n= \int_U f dx^1 dx^2 \cdots dx^n ∫U​ω=∫U​fdx1∧dx2∧…∧dxn=∫U​fdx1dx2⋯dxn

where the integral is taken over the open set U⊆MU \subseteq MU⊆M.

To make integral is well-defined and does not depend on the choice of local coordinates, we need to ensure that the integral is invariant under coordinate changes.

But according to the change of variables formula on integral over Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn, we only have:

∫Ufdx1dx2⋯dxn=∫Vf∣det⁡(∂yi∂xj)∣dy1dy2⋯dyn\int_U f dx^1dx^2 \cdots dx^n = \int_V f \left|\det\left(\frac{\partial y^i}{\partial x^j}\right)\right| dy^1 dy^2 \cdots dy^n ∫U​fdx1dx2⋯dxn=∫V​f​det(∂xj∂yi​)​dy1dy2⋯dyn

So to make the integral well-defined, we need to restrict the transformation to be orientation-preserving, i.e., det⁡(∂yi∂xj)>0\det\left(\frac{\partial y^i}{\partial x^j}\right) > 0det(∂xj∂yi​)>0.

We call the two charts (U,x)(U,x)(U,x) and (V,y)(V,y)(V,y) orientation-compactible if the Jacobian determinant det⁡(∂yi∂xj)\det\left(\frac{\partial y^i}{\partial x^j}\right)det(∂xj∂yi​) is positive for all points in U∩VU \cap VU∩V.

For a manifold, if all of the transition maps between charts are orientation-preserving, we say that the manifold is oriented. And if such a choice of orientation can be made, we call the manifold orientable. And we call such atlas A\mathcal{A}A an oriented atlas or orientation of the manifold MMM.

Integration on Manifolds

Let MMM be a smooth oriented manifold of dimension nnn. And let (ρ,U)(\rho, U)(ρ,U) be a smooth partition of unity subordinate to an open cover {Ui}i∈I\{U_i\}_{i \in I}{Ui​}i∈I​ of MMM, where ρi:M→[0,1]\rho_i: M \to [0,1]ρi​:M→[0,1] are smooth functions such that ∑i∈Iρi=1\sum_{i \in I} \rho_i = 1∑i∈I​ρi​=1 on MMM and supp(ρi)⊆Ui\text{supp}(\rho_i) \subseteq U_isupp(ρi​)⊆Ui​.
The integral of a differential nnn-form ω∈Ωn(M)\omega \in \Omega^n(M)ω∈Ωn(M) over the manifold MMM is defined as:

∫Mω=∑i∈I∫Uiρiω\int_M \omega = \sum_{i \in I} \int_{U_i} \rho_i \omega ∫M​ω=i∈I∑​∫Ui​​ρi​ω

where ρiω\rho_i \omegaρi​ω is a highest degree form on UiU_iUi​ and the integral is taken over the open set UiU_iUi​.

Note ρiω\rho_i \omegaρi​ω is compactly supported in UiU_iUi​ and is a smooth differential nnn-form on UiU_iUi​. So the integral ∫Uiρiω\int_{U_i} \rho_i \omega∫Ui​​ρi​ω is well-defined and finite.
The integral ∫Mω\int_M \omega∫M​ω is independent of the choice of partition of unity and the open cover {Ui}i∈I\{U_i\}_{i \in I}{Ui​}i∈I​.

Change of Variables

Let ϕ:M→N\phi: M \to Nϕ:M→N be a smooth map between oriented manifolds MMM and NNN of dimension nnn, with orientation A,B\mathcal{A,B}A,B respectively. We say that ϕ\phiϕ is orientation-preserving if for every chart (ψ,V)∈B(\psi, V)\in \mathcal{B}(ψ,V)∈B, the chart (ψ∘ϕ,ϕ−1(V))(\psi \circ \phi, \phi^{-1}(V))(ψ∘ϕ,ϕ−1(V)) is orientation-compactible with A\mathcal{A}A. We say that ϕ\phiϕ is orientation-reversing if for every chart (ψ,V)∈B(\psi, V)\in \mathcal{B}(ψ,V)∈B, the chart (ψ∘ϕ,ϕ−1(V))(\psi \circ \phi, \phi^{-1}(V))(ψ∘ϕ,ϕ−1(V)) is not orientation-compactible with A\mathcal{A}A.

Actually, mapping ϕ\phiϕ is either orientation-preserving or orientation-reversing if MMM and NNN are connected. Otherwise, it either preserves or reverses the orientation on each connected component of MMM and NNN.

The change of variables formula for the integral of a differential nnn-form ω∈Ωn(M)\omega \in \Omega^n(M)ω∈Ωn(M) under the map ϕ\phiϕ is given by:

if ϕ\phiϕ is an orientation-preserving map, then:

∫Nϕ∗ω=∫Mω\int_N \phi^* \omega = \int_M \omega ∫N​ϕ∗ω=∫M​ω

if ϕ\phiϕ is an orientation-reversing map, then:

∫Nϕ∗ω=−∫Mω\int_N \phi^* \omega = -\int_M \omega ∫N​ϕ∗ω=−∫M​ω

The relation of the orientability and the differential forms is given by the following theorem:

Theorem: A smooth manifold MMM is orientable if and only if there exists a nowhere vanishing differential nnn-form ω∈Ωn(M)\omega \in \Omega^n(M)ω∈Ωn(M).

And we call such nnn-form ω\omegaω a volume form on MMM.

Stokes Theorem

Induced Orientation on the Boundary

Let MnM^nMn be an oriented smooth manifold with boundary ∂M\partial M∂M. The boundary ∂M\partial M∂M is a smooth manifold of dimension n−1n-1n−1. And μ\muμ is a volume form on MMM that defines the orientation of MMM.

We can define an orientation on ∂M\partial M∂M induced by the orientation of MMM as follows:
At each point p∈∂Mp \in \partial Mp∈∂M, we can choose a local chart (Uα,x1,x2,…,xn)(U_{\alpha}, x^1, x^2, \ldots, x^n)(Uα​,x1,x2,…,xn) around ppp such that xn≥0x^n \geq 0xn≥0 on UαU_{\alpha}Uα​ and xn=0x^n = 0xn=0 on U∩∂MU \cap \partial MU∩∂M. The orientation on ∂M\partial M∂M is defined by the volume form:

ηα=ιenμ=ι−∂∂xnμ\eta_{\alpha}=\iota_{e_n} \mu = \iota_{-\frac{\partial}{\partial x^n}} \mu ηα​=ιen​​μ=ι−∂xn∂​​μ

where en=−∂∂xne_n = -\frac{\partial}{\partial x^n}en​=−∂xn∂​ is the outward-pointing normal vector field on ∂M\partial M∂M.

Or explicitly,

ηα=(−1)nfαdx1∧dx2∧…∧dxn−1\eta_{\alpha} = (-1)^{n} f_{\alpha} dx^1 \wedge dx^2 \wedge \ldots \wedge dx^{n-1} ηα​=(−1)nfα​dx1∧dx2∧…∧dxn−1

if μ=fαdx1∧dx2∧…∧dxn\mu = f_{\alpha} dx^1 \wedge dx^2 \wedge \ldots \wedge dx^nμ=fα​dx1∧dx2∧…∧dxn on UαU_{\alpha}Uα​.

And η\etaη gives a nowhere vanishing n−1n-1n−1 form on ∂M\partial M∂M.

To integrate a n−1n-1n−1-form ω\omegaω on ∂M\partial M∂M, we locally write

ω=(−1)nf dx1∧⋯∧dxn−1\omega = (-1)^n f\ dx^1\wedge \cdots \wedge dx^{n-1} ω=(−1)nf dx1∧⋯∧dxn−1

Then

∫Uω=∫Vf dx1⋯dxn−1\int_U \omega=\int_V f\ dx^1\cdots dx^{n-1} ∫U​ω=∫V​f dx1⋯dxn−1

The Stokes Theorem state that, for any ω∈Ωn−1(M)\omega \in \Omega^{n-1}(M)ω∈Ωn−1(M)

∫∂Mι∂M∗ω=∫Mdω\int_{\partial M} \iota_{\partial M}^* \omega = \int_{M} d\omega ∫∂M​ι∂M∗​ω=∫M​dω

Proof

If ω\omegaω is compactly support in coordinate chart (U,x)(U,x)(U,x)

ω=∑i(−1)i−1fidx1∧⋯∧dxi^∧⋯∧dxm\omega = \sum_{i}(-1)^{i-1}f_i dx^1\wedge\cdots\wedge\widehat{dx^i}\wedge\cdots\wedge dx^m\\ ω=i∑​(−1)i−1fi​dx1∧⋯∧dxi∧⋯∧dxm

If U≃RnU\simeq \mathbb R^{n}U≃Rn, ω\omegaω is 000 on ∂M\partial M∂M, then:

∫Udω=∫Rn∑i∂fi∂xidx1∧⋯∧dxm=∑i=1n∫Rn−1(∫−∞∞∂fi∂xidxi)dx1∧⋯∧dxi^∧⋯∧dxm=0=∫Mι∂M∗ω\begin{align*} \int_U d\omega &= \int_{\mathbb R^n}\sum_i \frac{\partial f_i}{\partial x^i} dx^1\wedge \cdots \wedge dx^m\\ &= \sum_{i=1}^n \int_{\mathbb R^{n-1}}\left(\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\frac{\partial f_i}{\partial x^i}dx^i\right) dx^1\wedge\cdots\wedge\widehat{dx^i}\wedge\cdots\wedge dx^m\\ &=0=\int_M \iota_{\partial M}^*\omega \end{align*} ∫U​dω​=∫Rn​i∑​∂xi∂fi​​dx1∧⋯∧dxm=i=1∑n​∫Rn−1​(∫−∞∞​∂xi∂fi​​dxi)dx1∧⋯∧dxi∧⋯∧dxm=0=∫M​ι∂M∗​ω​

If U≃R+nU\simeq \mathbb R^n_+U≃R+n​, then:

∫Udω=∫R+n∑i∂fi∂xidx1∧⋯∧dxm=∑i=1n−1∫Rn−1(∫−∞∞∂fi∂xidxi)dx1∧⋯∧dxi^∧⋯∧dxm+∫Rn−1(∫0∞∂fn∂xndxn)dx1∧⋯∧dxn−1=∫Rn−1fn(x1,⋯ ,xn−1,0)dx1∧⋯∧dxn−1=∫∂Mι∂M∗ω\begin{align*} \int_U d\omega &= \int_{\mathbb R^n_+}\sum_i \frac{\partial f_i}{\partial x^i} dx^1\wedge \cdots \wedge dx^m\\ &= \sum_{i=1}^{n-1} \int_{\mathbb R^{n-1}}\left(\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\frac{\partial f_i}{\partial x^i}dx^i\right) dx^1\wedge\cdots\wedge\widehat{dx^i}\wedge\cdots\wedge dx^m + \int_{\mathbb R^{n-1}}\left(\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\partial f_n}{\partial x^n}dx^n\right) dx^1\wedge\cdots\wedge dx^{n-1}\\ &= \int_{\mathbb R^{n-1}} f_n( x^1,\cdots,x^{n-1},0) dx^1\wedge\cdots\wedge dx^{n-1}\\ &=\int_{\partial M} \iota_{\partial M}^*\omega \end{align*} ∫U​dω​=∫R+n​​i∑​∂xi∂fi​​dx1∧⋯∧dxm=i=1∑n−1​∫Rn−1​(∫−∞∞​∂xi∂fi​​dxi)dx1∧⋯∧dxi∧⋯∧dxm+∫Rn−1​(∫0∞​∂xn∂fn​​dxn)dx1∧⋯∧dxn−1=∫Rn−1​fn​(x1,⋯,xn−1,0)dx1∧⋯∧dxn−1=∫∂M​ι∂M∗​ω​

The last step is because ι∂M∗(dxi)=dxi\iota_{\partial M}^*(dx^i)=dx^iι∂M∗​(dxi)=dxi for i=1,⋯ ,n−1i=1,\cdots,n-1i=1,⋯,n−1 and ι∂M∗(dxn)=0\iota_{\partial M}^*(dx^n)=0ι∂M∗​(dxn)=0.

For general ω\omegaω, we can use partition of unity to prove it.

de Rham Theory

Let MMM be a smooth manifold, ω∈Ωk(M)\omega \in \Omega^k(M)ω∈Ωk(M) be a smooth differential kkk-form. We call ω\omegaω a closed form if dω=0d\omega = 0dω=0, and we call ω\omegaω an exact form if there exists a differential (k−1)(k-1)(k−1)-form η∈Ωk−1(M)\eta \in \Omega^{k-1}(M)η∈Ωk−1(M) such that ω=dη\omega = d\etaω=dη.

We denote the space of closed kkk-forms on MMM as Zk(M)={ω∈Ωk(M):dω=0}Z^k(M) = \{\omega \in \Omega^k(M) : d\omega = 0\}Zk(M)={ω∈Ωk(M):dω=0} and the space of exact kkk-forms as Bk(M)={dη:η∈Ωk−1(M)}B^k(M) = \{d\eta : \eta \in \Omega^{k-1}(M)\}Bk(M)={dη:η∈Ωk−1(M)}.

Let dim⁡M=n\dim M = ndimM=n, we have the following result:

  • Bk(M)=Zk(M)={0}B^k(M) = Z^k(M) = \{0\}Bk(M)=Zk(M)={0} if k>nk > nk>n.
  • B0(M)={0}B^0(M) = \{0\}B0(M)={0}, Z0(M)={f∈C∞(M)∣df=0}≃RKZ^0(M) = \{f\in C^{\infty}(M) | df=0\}\simeq \mathbb{R}^{K}Z0(M)={f∈C∞(M)∣df=0}≃RK, where KKK is the number of connected components of MMM.
  • Zn(M)=Ωn(M)Z^n(M) = \Omega^n(M)Zn(M)=Ωn(M)

By definition,

Zk(M)=ker⁡(d:Ωk(M)→Ωk+1(M))Z^k(M) = \ker (d: \Omega^k(M) \to \Omega^{k+1}(M)) Zk(M)=ker(d:Ωk(M)→Ωk+1(M))

Bk(M)=im(d:Ωk−1(M)→Ωk(M))B^k(M) = \text{im} (d: \Omega^{k-1}(M) \to \Omega^k(M)) Bk(M)=im(d:Ωk−1(M)→Ωk(M))

Since d2=0d^2 = 0d2=0, we have the following property:

Bk(M)⊆Zk(M)⊆Ωk(M)B^k(M) \subseteq Z^k(M) \subseteq \Omega^k(M) Bk(M)⊆Zk(M)⊆Ωk(M)

We define the de Rham cohomology of MMM as:

HdRk(M)=Zk(M)/Bk(M)H^k_{dR}(M) = Z^k(M) / B^k(M) HdRk​(M)=Zk(M)/Bk(M)

and [ω][\omega][ω] is the equivalence class of ω∈Zk(M)\omega \in Z^k(M)ω∈Zk(M) in HdRk(M)H^k_{dR}(M)HdRk​(M), called the de Rham cohomology class of ω\omegaω.

HdRk(M)H^k_{dR}(M)HdRk​(M) is a vector space over R\mathbb{R}R and we shall see that it is linear with respect to the cup product.

Example:

For M=RM = \mathbb{R}M=R, Z0(R)=Ω0(R)=RZ^0(\mathbb{R}) = \Omega^0(\mathbb{R}) = \mathbb RZ0(R)=Ω0(R)=R, B0(R)={0}B^0(\mathbb{R}) = \{0\}B0(R)={0}, hence HdR0(R)≃RH^0_{dR}(\mathbb{R}) \simeq \mathbb{R}HdR0​(R)≃R, and HdRk(R)≃{0}H^k_{dR}(\mathbb{R}) \simeq \{0\}HdRk​(R)≃{0} for k>0k > 0k>0.

For M=S1M = \mathbb{S^1}M=S1, we know HdR0(S1)≃RH^0_{dR}(\mathbb{S^1}) \simeq \mathbb{R}HdR0​(S1)≃R and HdRk(S1)≃{0}H^k_{dR}(\mathbb{S^1}) \simeq \{0\}HdRk​(S1)≃{0} for k>1k > 1k>1. So we only need to compute HdR1(S1)H^1_{dR}(\mathbb{S^1})HdR1​(S1).

Z1(S1)=Ω1(S1)={fdθ∣f∈C∞(S1)}={fdθ∣f∈C∞(R),f periodic with period 2π}\begin{align*} Z^1(\mathbb{S^1}) = \Omega^1(\mathbb{S^1}) &= \{fd\theta|f\in C^{\infty}(\mathbb{S^1})\}\\ & = \{fd\theta | f\in C^{\infty}(\mathbb R), f \text{ periodic with period } 2\pi\}\\ \end{align*} Z1(S1)=Ω1(S1)​={fdθ∣f∈C∞(S1)}={fdθ∣f∈C∞(R),f periodic with period 2π}​

Now, consider ω∈B1(S1)\omega \in B^1(\mathbb{S^1})ω∈B1(S1), we have ω=dη\omega = d\etaω=dη for some η∈Ω0(S1)\eta \in \Omega^0(\mathbb{S^1})η∈Ω0(S1). Since η\etaη is a smooth function on S1\mathbb{S^1}S1, it can be expressed as f(θ)f(\theta)f(θ) for some periodic function fff with period 2π2\pi2π. Thus, we have:

ω=dη=df(θ)=g(θ)dθ\omega = d\eta = df(\theta) = g(\theta)d\theta ω=dη=df(θ)=g(θ)dθ

where ggg is a periodic function with period 2π2\pi2π and ∫02πg(θ)dθ=0\int_0^{2\pi} g(\theta) d\theta = 0∫02π​g(θ)dθ=0.
Thus, HdR1(S1)≃RH^1_{dR}(\mathbb{S^1}) \simeq \mathbb{R}HdR1​(S1)≃R, which is the first de Rham cohomology group of the circle since the cohomology class is represented by the integral value of the 1-form over the circle.

Let dim⁡M=n\dim M = ndimM=n, we have the following results:

  • HdRk(M)={0}H^k_{dR}(M) = \{0\}HdRk​(M)={0} for k>nk > nk>n.
  • HdR0(M)≃RKH^0_{dR}(M) \simeq \mathbb{R}^{K}HdR0​(M)≃RK, where KKK is the number of connected components of MMM.

Betti Numbers and Euler Characteristic

If dim⁡HdRk(M)<∞\dim H^k_{dR}(M) < \inftydimHdRk​(M)<∞ for any kkk, we define the Betti number

bk(M)=dim⁡HdRk(M)b_k(M) = \dim H^k_{dR}(M) bk​(M)=dimHdRk​(M)

which is called the kkk-th Betti number of the manifold MMM.

The Euler characteristic of MMM is defined as:

χ(M)=∑k=0dim⁡M(−1)kbk(M)\chi(M) = \sum_{k=0}^{\dim M} (-1)^k b_k(M) χ(M)=k=0∑dimM​(−1)kbk​(M)

From the above result, we know χ(R)=1−0=1\chi(\mathbb R) = 1 - 0 = 1χ(R)=1−0=1, and χ(S1)=1−1=0\chi(\mathbb{S^1}) = 1 - 1 = 0χ(S1)=1−1=0.

Pullback

Let F:M→NF: M \to NF:M→N be a smooth map between manifolds, the pullback of the de Rham cohomology is defined as:

F∗:HdRk(N)→HdRk(M)F^*: H^k_{dR}(N) \to H^k_{dR}(M) F∗:HdRk​(N)→HdRk​(M)

by F∗([ω])=[F∗ω]F^*([\omega]) = [F^*\omega]F∗([ω])=[F∗ω] for ω∈Zk(N)\omega \in Z^k(N)ω∈Zk(N).

Since dF∗=F∗ddF^*= F^*ddF∗=F∗d, F∗F^*F∗ maps closed forms to closed forms and exact forms to exact forms.

F∗(Bk(N))⊆Bk(M)andF∗(Zk(N))⊆Zk(M)F^*(B^k(N)) \subseteq B^k(M) \quad \text{and} \quad F^*(Z^k(N)) \subseteq Z^k(M) F∗(Bk(N))⊆Bk(M)andF∗(Zk(N))⊆Zk(M)

Hence F∗F^*F∗ induces a well-defined map on cohomology.

Note that the pullback of de Rham cohomology satisfies the contravariant functoriality:

  1. (F∘G)∗=G∗∘F∗(F \circ G)^* = G^* \circ F^*(F∘G)∗=G∗∘F∗ for smooth maps G:L→MG: L \to MG:L→M and F:M→NF: M \to NF:M→N.
  2. (idM)∗=idHdR∗(M)(\text{id}_M)^* = \text{id}_{H^*_{dR}(M)}(idM​)∗=idHdR∗​(M)​.

Thus, the de Rham cohomology is a contravariant functor from the category of smooth manifolds to the category of graded algebras over a field. So a diffeomorphism F:M→NF: M \to NF:M→N induces an isomorphism F∗:HdR∗(N)→HdR∗(M)F^*: H^*_{dR}(N) \to H^*_{dR}(M)F∗:HdR∗​(N)→HdR∗​(M).

Particularly, bk(M)b_k(M)bk​(M) and χ(M)\chi(M)χ(M) are diffeomorphism invariants.

Cup Product

Note that the wedge product ∧\wedge∧ on differential forms induces a operation on de Rham cohomology, called the cup product.

∪:HdRk(M)×HdRl(M)→HdRk+l(M)\cup: H^k_{dR}(M) \times H^l_{dR}(M) \to H^{k+l}_{dR}(M) ∪:HdRk​(M)×HdRl​(M)→HdRk+l​(M)

defined by

[ω1]∪[ω2]=[ω1∧ω2][\omega_1] \cup [\omega_2] = [\omega_1 \wedge \omega_2] [ω1​]∪[ω2​]=[ω1​∧ω2​]

for ω1∈Zk(M)\omega_1 \in Z^k(M)ω1​∈Zk(M) and ω2∈Zl(M)\omega_2 \in Z^l(M)ω2​∈Zl(M).

Assume ω1=dη1\omega_1 = d\eta_1ω1​=dη1​ and ω2=dη2\omega_2 = d\eta_2ω2​=dη2​, ω,ζ\omega,\zetaω,ζ are closed forms, to prove cup product is well-defined, we calculate

(ω+dη1)∧(ζ+dη2)=ω∧ζ+ω∧dη2+dη1∧ζ+dη1∧dη2=ω∧ζ+ω∧dη2+(−1)kdω∧η2−(−1)kdω∧dη2+dη1∧ζ+dη1∧dη2=ω∧ζ+d((−1)kω∧η2)+dη1∧ζ+dη1∧dη2=ω∧ζ+d((−1)kω∧η2)+d(η1∧ζ)+d(η1∧dη2)=ω∧ζ+d((−1)kω∧η2+η1∧ζ+η1∧dη2)\begin{align*} (\omega + d\eta_1) \wedge (\zeta + d\eta_2) &= \omega \wedge \zeta + \omega \wedge d\eta_2 + d\eta_1 \wedge \zeta + d\eta_1 \wedge d\eta_2\\ &= \omega \wedge \zeta + \omega \wedge d\eta_2 + (-1)^{k} d\omega \wedge \eta_2 - (-1)^{k} d\omega \wedge d\eta_2 \\ &+ d\eta_1 \wedge \zeta + d\eta_1 \wedge d\eta_2\\ &= \omega \wedge \zeta + d((-1)^{k} \omega \wedge \eta_2) + d\eta_1 \wedge \zeta + d\eta_1 \wedge d\eta_2 \\ &= \omega \wedge \zeta + d((-1)^{k} \omega \wedge \eta_2) + d(\eta_1 \wedge \zeta) + d(\eta_1 \wedge d\eta_2)\\ &= \omega \wedge \zeta + d\left ((-1)^{k} \omega \wedge \eta_2 + \eta_1 \wedge \zeta + \eta_1 \wedge d\eta_2\right) \end{align*} (ω+dη1​)∧(ζ+dη2​)​=ω∧ζ+ω∧dη2​+dη1​∧ζ+dη1​∧dη2​=ω∧ζ+ω∧dη2​+(−1)kdω∧η2​−(−1)kdω∧dη2​+dη1​∧ζ+dη1​∧dη2​=ω∧ζ+d((−1)kω∧η2​)+dη1​∧ζ+dη1​∧dη2​=ω∧ζ+d((−1)kω∧η2​)+d(η1​∧ζ)+d(η1​∧dη2​)=ω∧ζ+d((−1)kω∧η2​+η1​∧ζ+η1​∧dη2​)​

Therefore, we have

[ω+dη1]∪[ζ+dη2]=[ω∧ζ][\omega + d\eta_1] \cup [\zeta + d\eta_2] = [\omega \wedge \zeta] [ω+dη1​]∪[ζ+dη2​]=[ω∧ζ]

so the cup product is well-defined.

The cup product is bilinear, associative, and commutative up to a sign:

[ω1]∪[ω2]=[ω1∧ω2]=[(−1)klω2∧ω1]=(−1)kl[ω2]∪[ω1][\omega_1] \cup [\omega_2] = [\omega_1 \wedge \omega_2] = [(-1)^{kl} \omega_2 \wedge \omega_1] = (-1)^{kl} [\omega_2] \cup [\omega_1] [ω1​]∪[ω2​]=[ω1​∧ω2​]=[(−1)klω2​∧ω1​]=(−1)kl[ω2​]∪[ω1​]

The cup product induces a graded algebra structure on the de Rham cohomology:

HdR∗(M)=⨁k=0dim⁡MHdRk(M)H^*_{dR}(M) = \bigoplus_{k=0}^{\dim M} H^k_{dR}(M) HdR∗​(M)=k=0⨁dimM​HdRk​(M)

with the cup product ∪\cup∪ as the multiplication operation.

And (HdR∗(M),+,∪)(H^*_{dR}(M), +, \cup)(HdR∗​(M),+,∪) becomes a graded commutative ring with identity, called the de Rham cohomology ring of MMM.

Homotopy Invariance

We say MMM and NNN are homotopy equivalent if there exist continuous maps f:M→Nf: M \to Nf:M→N and g:N→Mg: N \to Mg:N→M such that g∘fg \circ fg∘f is homotopic to the identity map on MMM and f∘gf \circ gf∘g is homotopic to the identity map on NNN.

If MMM and NNN are homotopy equivalent, then HdRk(M)≃HdRk(N)H^k_{dR}(M) \simeq H^k_{dR}(N)HdRk​(M)≃HdRk​(N) for all kkk. This is stronger than the fact that HdRk(M)H^k_{dR}(M)HdRk​(M) is a diffeomorphism invariant, as homotopy equivalence does not even require the manifolds to have the same dimension, e.g. Rn∖{0}\mathbb R^n\setminus \{0\}Rn∖{0} and Sn−1\mathbb S^{n-1}Sn−1.

Note: This shows that the de Rham cohomology is determined by the topological structure of the manifold, not relevant to the smooth structure.

Poincaré Lemma

The Poincaré Lemma states that if UUU is a star-shape area in Rn\mathbb R^nRn, then HdRk(U)=0H^k_{dR}(U)=0HdRk​(U)=0 for k>1k>1k>1. Particularly, HDRk(Rn)=0H^k_{DR}(\mathbb R^n) = 0HDRk​(Rn)=0.

This is trivial since the star shape area can always contract to a point.

Moreover, since for any point in a manifold has a neighborhood that is diffeomorphic to a star shape area in Rn\mathbb R^nRn, we have the following collary:

For any kkk-th closed form ω∈Zk(M)\omega \in Z^k(M)ω∈Zk(M) and any p∈Mp\in Mp∈M, there is a neighborhood U∋pU\ni pU∋p and (k−1)(k-1)(k−1)-form η∈Ωk(U)\eta\in \Omega^k(U)η∈Ωk(U) such that ω=dη\omega = d \etaω=dη on UUU.

Proof of Homotopy Invariance

It suffices to prove that functor f⇝f∗f\rightsquigarrow f^*f⇝f∗ is homotopic invariant:

If two smooth maps f,g:M→Nf,g: M \to Nf,g:M→N are homotopic, then f∗=g∗:HdRk(N)→HdRk(M)f^* = g^*: H^k_{dR}(N) \to H^k_{dR}(M)f∗=g∗:HdRk​(N)→HdRk​(M).

Because assume this holds, if MMM and NNN are homotopy equivalent, we can use smooth approximations of the continuous maps to get smooth maps f:M→Nf: M \to Nf:M→N and g:N→Mg: N \to Mg:N→M such that g∘fg \circ fg∘f and f∘gf \circ gf∘g are homotopic to the identity maps on MMM and NNN, respectively. Then we have

(g∘f)∗=f∗∘g∗=idHdR∗(M)(g \circ f)^* = f^* \circ g^* = \text{id}_{H^*_{dR}(M)} (g∘f)∗=f∗∘g∗=idHdR∗​(M)​

(f∘g)∗=g∗∘f∗=idHdR∗(N)(f \circ g)^* = g^* \circ f^* = \text{id}_{H^*_{dR}(N)} (f∘g)∗=g∗∘f∗=idHdR∗​(N)​

which implies that f∗f^*f∗ and g∗g^*g∗ are isomorphisms.

Now we prove the claim that if f,g:M→Nf,g: M \to Nf,g:M→N are homotopic, then f∗=g∗f^* = g^*f∗=g∗.

We define the cochain homotopy as follows:

if f,g∈C∞(M,N)f,g\in C^{\infty}(M,N)f,g∈C∞(M,N) are homotopic. If there is a sequence of mapping hk:Ωk(M)→Ωk−1(M)h_k:\Omega^k(M) \to \Omega^{k-1}(M)hk​:Ωk(M)→Ωk−1(M) satisfying:

g∗−f∗=dMhk+hk+1dN.g^*-f^* = d_{M}h_k+h_{k+1}d_{N}. g∗−f∗=dM​hk​+hk+1​dN​.

we say the sequence h=(hk)h=(h_k)h=(hk​) is a cochain homotopy between f∗f^*f∗ and g∗g^*g∗.

If there exists such a cochain homotopy hhh, for any ω∈ZdRk(N)\omega \in Z^k_{dR}(N)ω∈ZdRk​(N)

g∗ω−f∗ω=(dhk+hk+1d)ω=d(hkω)+hk+1(dω)=d(hkω)∈Bk(M)g^*\omega - f^* \omega = (dh_{k}+h_{k+1}d)\omega = d(h_k\omega) +h_{k+1}(d\omega) = d(h_k\omega) \in B^k(M) g∗ω−f∗ω=(dhk​+hk+1​d)ω=d(hk​ω)+hk+1​(dω)=d(hk​ω)∈Bk(M)

So f∗([ω])=[f∗ω]=[g∗ω]=g∗([ω])f^*([\omega])=[f^*\omega] = [g^* \omega] = g^*([\omega])f∗([ω])=[f∗ω]=[g∗ω]=g∗([ω]).

Now we prove the existence of the cochain homotopy:

First, we prove a lemma
Let XXX be a complete vector field on MMM, ϕt\phi_tϕt​ be the flow generated by XXX. Then there exists a linear operator Qk:Ωk(M)→Ωk−1(M)Q_k:\Omega^k(M)\to\Omega^{k-1}(M)Qk​:Ωk(M)→Ωk−1(M) s.t. :

ϕ1∗ω−ω=dQk(ω)+Qk+1(dω)\phi_1^*\omega-\omega= d Q_k(\omega)+ Q_{k+1}(d\omega) ϕ1∗​ω−ω=dQk​(ω)+Qk+1​(dω)

Proof

ddtϕt∗ω=dds∣s=0ϕs+t∗=dds∣s=0ϕs∗ϕt∗ω=LX(ϕt∗ω)=dιX(ϕt∗ω)+ιXd(ϕt∗ω)\frac{d}{dt}\phi^*_t\omega=\left.\frac{d}{ds}\right|_{s=0}\phi^*_{s+t}=\left.\frac{d}{ds}\right|_{s=0}\phi^*_{s}\phi^*_{t}\omega=\mathcal{L}_X(\phi_t^*\omega)=d\iota_X(\phi^*_t\omega)+\iota_X d(\phi^*_t\omega) dtd​ϕt∗​ω=dsd​​s=0​ϕs+t∗​=dsd​​s=0​ϕs∗​ϕt∗​ω=LX​(ϕt∗​ω)=dιX​(ϕt∗​ω)+ιX​d(ϕt∗​ω)

Therefore, denote Qk(ω)=∫01ιX(ϕt∗ω)dtQ_k(\omega)=\int_{0}^{1}\iota_X(\phi_t^*\omega)dtQk​(ω)=∫01​ιX​(ϕt∗​ω)dt

ϕ1∗ω−ω=∫01(ddtϕt∗ω)=dQk(ω)+Qk+1(dω)\phi_1^*\omega-\omega = \int_{0}^{1}\left (\frac{d}{dt}\phi^*_t\omega\right ) = dQ_k(\omega) + Q_{k+1}(d\omega) ϕ1∗​ω−ω=∫01​(dtd​ϕt∗​ω)=dQk​(ω)+Qk+1​(dω)

de Rham Theorem

The famous de Rham theorem states that the de Rham cohomology is isomorphic to the singular cohomology with real coefficients, i.e., for any smooth manifold MMM,

HdRk(M)≃Hsingk(M;R)H^k_{dR}(M) \simeq H^k_{sing}(M; \mathbb{R}) HdRk​(M)≃Hsingk​(M;R)

which we shall not prove here.

This theorem reveals the duality between the topological structure and the algebraic structure (differential forms) on a manifold.

Chain Complex

The chain complex is a sequence of abelian groups (or modules) ⋯A0,A1,A2⋯\cdots A_0, A_1, A_2\cdots⋯A0​,A1​,A2​⋯ connected by homomorphisms dn:An→An−1d_n: A_n\to A_{n-1}dn​:An​→An−1​, such that the image of one homomorphism is contained in the kernel of the next. The composition of any two consecutive maps shall be the zero maps, $ d_n \circ d_{n+1} = 0$ or d2=0d^2=0d2=0 for short.

⋯←d0A0←d1A1←d2A2←d3⋯\cdots \xleftarrow{d_0} A_0 \xleftarrow{d_1} A_1 \xleftarrow{d_2} A_2 \xleftarrow{d_3} \cdots ⋯d0​​A0​d1​​A1​d2​​A2​d3​​⋯

The cochain complex is the dual notion to the chain complex.

⋯→d0A0→d1A1→d2A2→d3⋯\cdots \xrightarrow{d^0} A^0 \xrightarrow{d^1} A^1 \xrightarrow{d^2} A^2 \xrightarrow{d^3} \cdots ⋯d0​A0d1​A1d2​A2d3​⋯

where dn∘dn+1=0d^{n}\circ d^{n+1} = 0dn∘dn+1=0.

The elements in the kernel of ddd are called (co)cycles (or closed elements), and the elements in the image of ddd are called (co)boundaries (or exact elements). Right from the definition of the differential, all boundaries are cycles. The nnn-th (co)homology group Hn(Hn)H_n(H^n)Hn​(Hn) is the group of (co)cycles modulo (co)boundaries in degree nnn, that is,

Hn=ker⁡dn/im dn+1(Hn=ker⁡dn/im dn−1)H_n = \ker d_n/\text{im } d_{n+1} \left ( H^n = \ker d^n/\text{im } d^{n-1}\right) Hn​=kerdn​/im dn+1​(Hn=kerdn/im dn−1)

A exact sequence is a (co)chain complex whose (co)homology groups are all zero, which means all closed elements are exact. A short exact sequence is a bounded exact sequence in which only the groups AkA_kAk​, Ak+1A_{k+1}Ak+1​, Ak+2A_{k+2}Ak+2​ may be nonzero. For example, the following chain complex is a short exact sequence.

⋯→0→Z→×pZ↠Z/p→0→⋯\cdots \rightarrow 0 \rightarrow Z \xrightarrow {\times p} Z \twoheadrightarrow Z/p \rightarrow 0 \rightarrow \cdots ⋯→0→Z×p​Z↠Z/p→0→⋯

de Rham Complex

The de Rham complex is the sequence of differential forms:

0→Ω0(M)→dΩ1(M)→dΩ2(M)→d…→dΩn(M)→00 \to \Omega^0(M) \xrightarrow{d} \Omega^1(M) \xrightarrow{d} \Omega^2(M) \xrightarrow{d} \ldots \xrightarrow{d} \Omega^n(M) \to 0 0→Ω0(M)d​Ω1(M)d​Ω2(M)d​…d​Ωn(M)→0
